PETITION.TITLE: Austudy: Family Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain electors of Queensland points out to the Senate that the 1990/91 Federal Budget stipulates that from January next year Family Allowance payments will be subject to an assets test. Family Allowance will be withdrawn if net assets excluding the family home and debt exceed $300,000. Furthermore the parental assets test threshold for Family Allowance Supplement, Austudy and Assistance for Isolated Children has been severely slashed in the 1990/91 Federal Budget.

Considering the economic crisis facing rural communities in Australia, assets tests of such a nature are not viable because the assets are incapable of generating enough income to sustain families and send children away for schooling.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to exempt the family farm from the assets test for Austudy, Family Allowance and Family Allowance Supplement.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 and examining the proposed expenditure for the Department of Administrative Services. The question before the Chair is that the amendment moved by Senator Short to the motion that the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to support the amendment which has been moved by Senator Short, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add'', subject to the following request for amendment to the House of Representatives: That the House of Representatives be requested to amend the Bill by reducing the vote for the Department of Administrative Services by $1,028,596, because of the decision to write off as irrecoverable money which the High Court has ruled was unlawfully paid out as postage entitlement for certain members of the Parliament.

In response to that motion moved by Senator Short last night the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) made a most extraordinary speech, allegedly in defence of the Government and in opposition to this amendment. It was a speech in which he did not seek at any stage to defend the conduct of the Government in relation to this whole sordid affair.

In so far as the Minister's speech contained any argument at all-I have rarely heard a speech in this chamber so lacking in argument-he seemed to be saying, firstly, that the Opposition should not be moving this amendment because the Australian Democrats are not going to support it. The other argument seemed to be that the Opposition should not be moving a request to change in any way an Appropriation Bill.

I want to deal firstly with those two arguments, although they hardly deserve much attention. The first argument that the Opposition is flogging a dead horse, that the whole issue is presumably a dead duck and that the Opposition should simply not be proceeding with this request because the Democrats will not support it, is a most incredible argument for this Government, or any government, to put forward. It comes particularly surprisingly from a member of the present Government, members of which have poured scorn on the views of the Democrats, in many cases quite justifiably, on innumerable occasions.

It is also surprising that the Government should say that the Opposition should not proceed with the amendment because the Democrats are not going to support it when, in fact, time and again the Government has voted against proposals of the Democrats. A lot of those proposals have been passed only because of the support of the Opposition. So the argument that the Opposition should not be proceeding because the Democrats are not supporting us is totally absurd and does not deserve any further consideration.

Let us consider for a moment the claim that the Minister uses-it seems to be his only argument-that this is a dead horse, to use a phrase of Senator Powell's. This was her immediate of-the-cuff reaction when she first heard of the Opposition's moves in this direction a couple of weeks ago. It was obviously a reaction she made without having given the matter any further thought.

I hope that, having had the opportunity of giving it further thought and listening to the arguments here today, Senator Powell will recall her stance and that of her Australian Democrats colleagues only a few months ago in this chamber on Senator Parer's amendment to the Parliamentary Entitlements Bill 1990 to reduce the figure for postage proposed by the Government from $30,000 to $9,000, as was allowed by the Remuneration Tribunal.

Only a few months ago Senator Powell supported very firmly and effectively in that debate the principle that the Opposition has maintained throughout. She in fact was supported by some other of her colleagues, including Senator Lees. I hope that Senator Lees will be consistent in her attitude in this debate. Senator Powell was also supported by Senator Jenkins who, of course, is no longer in the chamber. Other Democrats did not support that view. Nevertheless, there were sufficient Democrats, along with Senator Vallentine and Senator Harradine, who supported the Opposition.

Our position was supported by the Senate. The Parliamentary Entitlements Act 1990 has now restored the position of the Remuneration Tribunal in determining this postage figure at the traditional amount of about $9,000. So this matter is by no means a dead horse because it was a very live one only a few months ago.

What has happened since is that the Government has totally ignored not only the decision of the High Court of Australia but also of the Parliament. The position is that the Government has now decided not to take any further action to recover the $1m that was wrongfully spent. One can call it illegal or unlawful. Senator Bolkus preferred the words `without authority'. He admitted that it was done without authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ultra vires.

—It was done ultra vires. There are all sorts of words that one could use. But the fact of the matter is that this money was paid out when it should not have been and the Government has now decided to do nothing about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Even if the legal opinion which was received from the Solicitor-General is correct-and there is certainly a lot of debate about that; I do not want to go into the debate on that subject here because it will be the subject of litigation-it only emphasises further the mess the Government got into by its own actions.

I would also like to refer to the suggestion that this issue is a dead horse. A few days after the Opposition announced its position, the Sydney Morning Herald in an editorial of 9 November, which has been referred to by my colleague Senator Short, had this to say:

It's about time, too, that the Federal Government acknowledged it has mishandled the issue. Instead of ensuring that repayments are never made, it should be encouraging those of its MPs who spent their allowances to pay the money back. There is an issue of political integrity involved here. How can the Federal Government expect people to respond to its calls for restraint in spending when it allows its MPs to spend money to which they had no legal right?

They were the views of a responsible leading newspaper in Australia a few days after this move by the Opposition was described by Senator Powell as a dead horse. The fact is that it is very much alive and running. It is no wonder that the polls show that the Government now has all time record low support. This morning's news indicates that it has only 32 per cent support of the people in this country. No wonder that is the position that the Government is in when it behaves the way it has in this case from the beginning right up until now. It apparently continues to refuse to do the right thing in relation to this matter.

One other very weak argument was used by Senator Bolkus; that is, that the Opposition has no business to be putting forward a request to an appropriation Bill. No Opposition in this country has ever denied itself the right or the power, which it has in the Constitution, and always has had, to make requests on money Bills or to oppose money Bills. The Senate has done so on countless occasions over the years. It is not simply a question of 1975, it is a procedure which is frequently adopted in this chamber. The Australian Democrats have frequently moved amendments to money Bills; they have frequently amended them. They have sought to deny the Government revenue time and time again. There is nothing sacrosanct whatever in our Constitution about a money Bill; in fact, the Government is about to make a request to one of its own money Bills in the Budget process that is going on now.

A Bill has come into this chamber which imposes an assets test on family allowances of $300,000. That is what the Government's own money Bill, Budget Bill, says. Senator Richardson has just announced that that will be changed from $300,000 to $500,000. How will it be changed? It will be changed in this chamber at the request of the Government itself. So what is sacrosanct about a money Bill? The Government will change its own Budget quite shortly to reduce taxation levels on which the Budget was formulated.

It is an absolutely ridiculous argument to suggest that the Opposition is somehow out of order in making a request for a very modest change in a Budget of $90 billion, or thereabouts. The Opposition is making a very modest request that it be reduced by $1m. The fact is that the Government has lost $1m, unlawfully, ultra vires, without authority and illegally, by its mishandling, which is a rather gentle way of putting it. The Government thought that it was a very clever rort to help its supporters in the House of Representatives in a forthcoming election, which looked a very difficult one indeed.

There is simply no substance whatever in the arguments which the Minister put forward in opposition to the amendment that has been moved by Senator Short. Senator Short has submitted very major arguments as to the principles on which the Opposition has moved this motion. The fact is that at all times there has been a breach by the Government of a fundamental provision of the Constitution. There has to be a legal appropriation from Consolidated Revenue. Section 83 of the Constitution reads:
No money shall be drawn from the Treasury of the Commonwealth except under appropriation made by law.

The Government in this affair sought, at all times, to avoid coming to Parliament to get that authority. It said that it had the power to do it by Executive act. Goodness only knows how on earth it had that power, but it said that it had it. The High Court said clearly that it did not have it. When the Government was ultimately forced to come to Parliament because of the High Court decision, this chamber, including Senator Powell and Senator Lees, supported the denial of that outrageous postage allowance for members of the House of Representatives. When the Government finally asked, the Parliament denied it the right. The High Court said clearly that it had to go to the Parliament; it went, and it failed. For those reasons alone the Government should be suffering a reduction in its Budget to pay for the losses that it has incurred by its own decision-not by anybody else, not by any individual, but by a decision of the Government. The Government, from the beginning to the end, has to carry the responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very hard to know where to start. For eight years this Opposition has refused, on the vast majority of occasions, to join with the Australian Democrats to improve Government legislation, particularly money Bills concerning issues like delaying pension payments to the most needy in our community; imposing prescription fees on pensioners, again; imposing charges on tertiary students; limiting access to the young homeless allowance; and refusing to take sales tax off recycled goods-paper in the first instance and, most recently, plastic goods-and equipment for the disabled. The list goes on and on of where the Democrats have sought Opposition support to amend money Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Over that same period of time we have been coming into this chamber, week after week, for the appropriations debate-which is about Supply Bills-listening to endless hours of discussion, debate and inquisition, which is really destined to change nothing as the commitment of the Australian Democrats not to block Supply is firm and has been restated year after year. That debate has done nothing other than service the egos of a few people on the Opposition benches.

Then we come in here today and hear someone of Senator Durack's eminence again confuse money Bills and Supply Bills. In all of that time, out in the community and up in the gallery, the Opposition has chosen to confuse money Bills and Supply Bills. It always went out to the community and said, `We couldn't support that Democrat amendment to help pensioners, students or children because that would have put Supply at risk, and we don't want to block Supply'.

Suddenly, a couple of weeks ago the Opposition found itself a dead horse to flog and actually said to the media, `On this one, we will go as far as to block Supply'. This is an Appropriation Bill, not a money Bill.
Senator Knowles interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Knowles, I called you to order earlier.

—I commend to everybody here, particularly new senators and certainly the members of the press gallery, an excellent paper by the Clerk of the Senate, Harry Evans, which makes quite clear what the difference is between Appropriation Bills and money Bills. I am also happy to provide from my office a list of occasions on which the Opposition has wimped out on money Bills. There are plenty of letters to the editors in Opposition senators' local papers excusing their inexcusable behaviour on that matter, and confusing Supply and money Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition now comes in here with all sorts of accusations about the previous positions of me and some of my colleagues. Let me make quite clear what happened when the issue of the stamps first came up here in this chamber. For a start, I can tell Senator Durack that I did vote but I did not contribute to the debate. At that time we were debating an Opposition amendment which, in essence, was to support the reinstatement of the Remuneration Tribunal's position on the matter. I did support the Opposition on that and I still believe that those of us who went that way did the right thing. It was a matter on which Democrat members were split-it happens from time to time that there is a clash of principles or a clash of views-nevertheless, I stand by that vote. That is not the same as the vote I am being asked to support on this occasion. That reinstatement has been made, and it stands.

Subsequently, the situation has reverted to a political exercise. The decision not to recover the money is now out of the hands of the Parliament and in the hands of the Government, unless of course we are prepared to block Supply to make a political point. The Democrats have always said that we will not block Supply and we will certainly not block Supply to make this particular political point. I suggest to Opposition senators that if they feel vehemently about the so-called loss of $1m or so-I make one aside on that point as it appears that if the Government were to recover the money it would probably recover it from its own Australia Post into its own Department of Administrative Services; so I do not know what kind of recovery that is-a real recovery of at least a quarter of that money could be had if the former Leader of the National Party of Australia, Charles Blunt, were to pay back what is, at the very least, dubious stamp expenditure on his behalf. At least a quarter of that money from a former member of the Opposition could return to the coffers of the Government, if that is really the concern of the Opposition.

We know that that is not the concern of the Opposition. We know that this is a political exercise of flogging a dead horse by an Opposition which hardly seems to know which way is up on the question of money Bills and Supply Bills. When it was announced that the Opposition was going to make this move on the Appropriation Bills, Opposition spokespeople also stated that this matter would be pursued, if necessary, to the point of blocking Supply. This is an Appropriation Bill, and after eight years of pursuing amendment after amendment to money Bills the Democrats are quite clear on the difference between money Bills and Supply Bills. In this case we are not in any way prepared to give the Opposition what it wants-an excuse to block Supply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment that has been moved by Senator Short. I have no difficulty with the precise distinction between a Supply Bill and a money Bill, but I do not know whether we are getting off the track. Is there any question that Senator Short's amendment is contrary to Standing Orders? There is no question of that.
—No, I didn't say that. It goes to the House of Representatives and, if they reject it, it comes back here.

—I understand the procedure. There is no confusion about the situation. The amendment put forward by Senator Short is in fact within Standing Orders and within the power of the Senate. That being the case, one needs to look at the merits of that question. I would be very hesitant indeed to support this motion if it did not go to the responsibility of parliamentarians as a whole to uphold the integrity of members of parliament and their standing. I am not talking about our own personal standing but our integrity to be able to pursue properly the interests of the people who have elected us. In saying that, I do not point the bone at any of the Government members in the other place who expended this money prior to the last election, because they did so on the clear understanding that the money they had received for postal allowances was provided properly by the Government. Therefore, it is the Government that is found to have been wanting.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night, in the Committee of the Whole, the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, agreed with Senator Short that the action of the Government has been found to be ultra vires. Therefore, the Parliament itself must be involved in that situation. The amount of money is not great-it is a little over $1m-but a principle is involved, that principle being whether this Parliament, in particular the Senate, is able to exercise its functions of audit and control over a government expending money when it is not authorised so to do. That is the principle with which we are dealing at this moment. That is why I am prepared-because of the extraordinary situation and the fact that the Government has expended money in an unauthorised fashion-to support the motion that has been moved by Senator Short.

It has been said that it is a dead horse. I know a bit about the racing industry and I wonder who has nobbled the horse. I wonder whether the people of Australia, having put their money on the horse-which in this case has the integrity of parliamentarians and the integrity of Parliament riding on it-do not deserve to have a steward's inquiry. There has been a steward's inquiry-namely, through the High Court. That steward's inquiry has found that the Government acted in an unauthorised manner. We should really be warning the Government off this particular course. If we do not take this action now, who is to say that this Government or any future government will not do precisely the same thing and use precisely the same excuses and get away with the unauthorised expenditure of public moneys. I believe Senator Short's amendment will put a check-a rein, if you like-on such illegitimate government actions in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Short's amendment and also to commend Senator Harradine on what I thought was a most eloquent exposition of the situation as it stands. I think it is proper to go back and recount briefly the whole sordid story and explain the reason that we are debating this matter today. The Remuneration Tribunal had the role of determining the postage allowance for members of the House of Representatives and the Senate. It made a determination at the end of 1988 that that figure would be $9,000. In July 1989 the then Minister for Administrative Services decided that the executive Government would determine the postage allowance. In December 1989 it increased the allowance for the House of Representatives from $9,000 to $30,000 per member.

SPEECH.PARA: A press release was put out-I see Senator Kernot nodding; she will remember this well-that said that this was done to enable members of the House of Representatives to write to their electors once a year. It was phoney; everyone knew it was phoney. It was done to enable members of the House of Representatives-particularly those in the Australian Labor Party-to use that postage allowance simply for the direct mail campaign which was set up for them.
It was interesting to note that the amount was not increased for senators. Of course, the reason for that, as everyone was aware, was that it disadvantaged the Labor Party to go along that route.

TALK.START.PARA: —It disadvantaged the Democrats.

—Senator Powell is quite right. It was a great disadvantage to the Australian Democrats and their former leader who was standing for a seat in the House of Representatives. The whole thing was shoddy from the word go. Even the press release put out by the then Minister was dishonest-and we all knew it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon. Neil Brown took this matter to the High Court of Australia, which found five to nil that the actions of the Government were illegal. The then Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr Peacock, advised his members not to overspend because the High Court had found it was illegal, but the then Minister for Administrative Services put out a press release saying, `Spend, spend, spend; it is okay'. Following the election the Government brought in the Parliamentary Entitlements Bill, the legislation to which Senator Powell referred. The purpose of that legislation was to validate retrospectively something the High Court had found to be invalid. To their credit, Senator Powell, Senator Lees, Senator Harradine and Senator Vallentine supported the Opposition in throwing out the legislation, which would have retrospectively validated something found to be illegal.

In the debate that went on I asked a series of questions of the Minister. The major thrust of those questions was: why are you introducing this legislation when we all know it is to validate retrospectively something that is illegal? We did not get a satisfactory answer, except that the Minister said that on legal advice-which the Government would not produce-the Government could not collect the money, so it might as well validate it. A few other red herrings were thrown in, such as saying that some other entitlements for members of the House of Representatives might also be at risk because of the decision by the High Court. However, the Government failed, thanks to the support given by some of the Democrats and some of the independents.

Senator Powell has just said that she supported the Opposition's amendment to that Bill to enable the postage question to go back to the Remuneration Tribunal, where it should have remained in the first place. With respect to Senator Powell, that was not the background to the Opposition's amendment. The basis of that amendment was not to support something which retrospectively validated an act found to be illegal by the High Court.

Having lost that, the Government then decided that it would waive the debt. Had the Government made some attempt to collect that debt, we might not be engaging in this debate today. No attempt was made whatsoever, and I know no-one in society who would say that we could not collect the debt without having at least attempted to collect it.
In the Estimates Committee I asked a question of one of the officers of the Department of Administrative Services. I will repeat that question:
How can it be concluded by anyone that the amounts were irrecoverable if the people who had spent it had never been asked to pay the money voluntarily?

That question was never answered. Subsequently I applied under the freedom of information legislation for the legal advice which the Government claimed it had from sources within the Attorney-General's Department but which it refused to provide to members of the Senate. I might say that it was an interesting exercise. All I sought was a copy of the legal advice which has now subsequently been tabled in the other place. I received everything but the legal advice. In fact, I received a complete list of overspending by all members and a couple of senators, which I believe is not very accurate, but that does not matter. Although I did not ask for it, I received a list of spending by every member of the House of Representatives. That list is publicly available and I would be happy to table it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including Mr Blunt's?
—I think you should table it.
—I seek leave to table that document.
—I would like to look at it first.
—It is just the document from freedom of information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would still like to look at it.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the crux of the situation today. The Government waived a debt found by the High Court to be illegal but, more importantly, it was a debt the Government made no attempt to collect. No-one was asked to repay the debt, hence the request by Senator Short.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a further comment on freedom of information: it can be a costly exercise. Having been through it, I wonder whether I would do it again because I received a lot of information, but not the information I sought. The excuse given to me for not providing that legal information was a little thing called `legal professional privilege'. I am not sure to this day why the information was not provided, because it was subsequently tabled in another place. That will be the subject of further litigation, as the Minister mentioned, so I will not go into that.

In conclusion, the Executive Government made a decision for purely political purposes. It put its snout in the public trough to run its election campaign. The Government called it something else, but found it could not retrospectively validate it because of support given in this chamber by the others I have mentioned, as well as by members of the coalition. The Government has now waived the debt without making any attempt to collect it. I think that is most reprehensible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very simple thing. I believe the Australian Democrats are trying to muddy the waters by saying that they will not support us because we had not supported them previously on many issues on which they would have liked our support.

However, on this occasion the High Court is saying that the Government should not be using that money.

We have been sickened to death by the Democrats telling us that they are here not to take government but to keep the bastards honest. We have a High Court decision that this Government was wrong and spent money it should not have spent. What do the Democrats say? They say the High Court's decision is not worth following up. Because we follow up its decision, we are-what is it, Senator Powell?-flogging a dead horse. The Democrats are not concerned about upholding a unanimous decision of the High Court. It is inexplicable to me that the Democrats could possibly deny the High Court's decision. I do not understand them.

I understand the Government's attitude, because it has been hauled before the High Court by us on several occasions. The Government may remember the High Court decision on the referendum. We dragged the Government before the High Court and won. We have won several times. The Government is not acting any differently. The Australian people must understand that this small group of senators are not the people they have ever claimed to be because of this particular decision. When the crunch comes, they will support the Labor Party on any illegal deal because they are prepared to allow the Government to override the High Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Mr Keating and his tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask the Australian Democrats what happened to their principle of `keeping the bastards honest'. The Democrats were brought into existence to `keep the bastards honest'. The `bastards' are sitting opposite. They are dishonest; they are using illegal funds. The Democrats have the opportunity to keep them honest, and what do they do? They crawl over with them. They should get up and explain why they crawl over with them. Perhaps they will get a few extra staff or a few extra trips. It is a different party altogether from the one that was originally formed by Mr Don Chipp.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened to the Democrats? I suggest that their change in direction is being well noted. That is what the public thinks of the Democrats because they have changed their spots from those of the original party. It is a 20 per cent loss on the support that they had. I ask Senator Kernot, a good Queenslander-and she has been through a State where there have been rorts and rorts and rorts; she knows what it is all about and that people go to gaol for it-why she is going to let this Government off the hook, to let it spend this money illegally. I ask Senator Kernot and Senator Spindler why they are going to let those opposite off the hook. Why are they going to let them spend money illegally? Senator Powell spoke to us in what I can only say was confused righteousness. What she voted for was principally right the last time we took a vote on this matter. It is a decision of government that we be publicly funded. Why do they let the lot opposite spend another $1m of taxpayers' money in publicly funded electioneering? If they want to do that, let them move a motion that we increase the public funding. If that is what they want, they should do it deliberately. They should let the public see what they are on about. They should not do it through the back door by supporting the people opposite in $1m of publicly funded electioneering which we want them to pay back. The Democrats reckon they are going to keep them honest, and what do they do? They crawl over there with them like the political ladies of the night that they probably are.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to introduce a couple of new matters which may resolve some of the problems the Australian Democrats have. I am disappointed to see the Australian Democrats Whip, whom I regard very highly, leaving because I want to address a couple of matters to him. As a reasonable man, he will recognise the merit of what I am saying.
—As a reasonable man, I am revolted by what I have been hearing for the last 10 minutes.

—I am glad to hear that the Democrats are keen to listen to what I hope to be a reasonable argument. I am addressing them, I hope, as reasonable people. I am presenting an argument which, I hope, will bring a response from the floor of the chamber because the general response so far from the Australian Democrats has been that this is an exercise to try to block Supply and that the amendment moved by Senator Short to block the recovery of an illegal payment is an attempt to block Supply.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the Australian Democrats and the chamber to a whole series of debates. Let us start off on 2 October 1951 when a gentleman called Dr Evatt, who was Leader of the Opposition at the time, moved that the first item of the appropriations be reduced by one pound. That was the traditional device, the reduction of the appropriations by an amount-and it varied; one pound in this case was a formal protest. Dr Evatt said that by moving this motion he would be compelling a revision of the Budget. He believed that by doing so the Parliament would:

. . . save the people from the dangers of avoidable recession and depression. The object of the Opposition is to force a revision of the budget insofar as it imposes taxes, levies, and duties. That is essential in the national interest, and that is why I move, on behalf of the Labour party.
That the first item be reduced by one pound.

We can say, `Okay, that is just an objective, a gesture which is not meaningful'. The fact is that reduction of the Estimates by an amount is not blocking Supply and never has been. It is phoney and dishonest of anyone, particularly the Labor Party, to pretend so. I am glad to see that it has not run this line of garbage.

Obviously, the Democrats do not have a sufficient sense of history. No wonder! They are going to be very fleeting creatures on the face of history. Having no sense of history, they have not bothered to find out that it was not so long ago in this chamber that the following motion was carried. Senator Poyser moved that the House of Representatives be requested to amend the vote by reducing it by $1. It was carried 23 to 22. The walls did not collapse. Supply was not blocked.

There is such a total volume of nonsense coming out about this blocking of Supply that I am intrigued that media representatives, who should have a sense of history, have been unable to establish the truth, have listened to this garbage and have printed with large print that the Opposition is threatening to block Supply.

I say that when this request was carried to the House of Representatives there was no dissolution, no double dissolution, no shock, no horror; nothing. The Opposition's motion is simply an extension of that device to cover the recouping of an illegal payment, one found to be illegal by a unanimous decision of the High Court.

By the way, the Labor Party did not keep its moves to reduce the Budget to small amounts like one pound, the equivalent of $2. It in fact raised the ante. Back in 1970, Labor's Senator Bishop moved that the House of Representatives be requested to amend the vote by reducing it by $10. If the Government stays here for much longer, I suppose the current value of $10 could well end up at $1m. But what we have to establish very clearly is that, if the Democrats really look at this issue, they will see it is not an attempt to block Supply whatsoever. Supply proceeds quite clearly and uncomplicatedly, and in fact what is happening is very clear and very simple. It is what has happened in the past, and the Labor Party is making no comment about it because it is what it has done consistently.

The Democrats have no understanding of the democratic process, and it is very interesting indeed that the word `honest' has been brought up in connection with the role of the Democrats. I would have thought that there is one very simple proposition, and that is: if you break the law, you are not acting honestly. I would have thought if one were dedicated and committed to the concept of honesty, particularly maintaining honesty in a public institution, one would be committed to the concept of maintaining the law-maintaining the law where, in fact, it is found that a payment was not in keeping with the law. It was not an honest payment, and a failure to recoup it is not honest. A failure to attempt to recoup it is blatantly dishonest. So here we have a situation where the Democrats are refusing to require the Government to seek to recoup it; they are refusing to force it by denying it the cash in this context. The Democrats are refusing to force the Government into honest behaviour.

I am intrigued at some of the interjections that have been made and, if they have not been recorded in Hansard-and maybe they were not because the speaker at the time did not respond to them-I think we should make certain that they are recorded. For example, Senator Powell interjected when one of our speakers-I cannot remember who it was now-was saying that it was the law which was being broken. Her response was, `We put pensioners above the law'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.
—What did you say? Would you like to correct your interjection?
—If the Chair will call one of us, we will stand up and speak.

—Good, I would be overjoyed. If Senator Powell denies that she said they put pensioners above the law, I would be interested to see how she changes the words to make it sound less, if you like, contemptuous of the law and I would be overjoyed then to have an opportunity to respond to her. In the absence of her response, can I say that if that is her view, if that contemptuous approach to the rule of law is what prompts the Democrats, then I can understand why they are refusing to support Senator Short's motion to bring honesty to this Government and to deny a government and its members the opportunity, illegally, to take advantage of a payment which should never have been made.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is also worth mentioning that there does seem to be some confusion in the minds of the Democrats about the Opposition's approach to money Bills. I would have thought that they would have heard of the Guilfoyle interpretation, which generally is that a government is entitled to its Budget-particularly a government that has recently been elected. The big question we have to face in this case is this: did the electorate know when it voted for this Government that members of the Government had in fact grossly and disgracefully appropriated to themselves-quite illegally, through a gimmick, a device-$30,000 to promote their election prospects; that the election was in fact won partly on a fraud?

TALK.START.PARA: —What did Charlie Blunt do?

—I will accept that interjection and ask Senator Schacht to consider seriously whether he wants to enter into that debate, because he must be aware that we all hold many examples. It is also of the view that Supply, as we have heard in the past, is not something that should be blocked in any situation other than total disaster. I might remind the chamber that, when Supply was blocked last time-in a totally different situation anyway-the democratic result was that the people of Australia gave their judgment. I would have thought, just in passing, that even the Democrats would accept the fact that maybe the people of Australia do have a right to express a view at a time of crisis. But maybe the Democrats, like the Labor Party, believe that the people of Australia do not have the capacity or the intellect to make decisions when there is in fact a time of crisis.

But in that circumstance I think it is quite clear that this Budget, the first Budget after an election, contains in it a major element in terms of principle which was not presented to the people of Australia at the time the Budget was brought down. Not one of these people who was on the receiving end of this money has offered to return it-which strikes me as interesting-and this Government has not required its return. It seems to me that, in the face of such a clear High Court decision, this is a matter of grave concern. This amendment moved by Senator Short strikes at the very heart of this Government's dishonesty. One would have thought that $1m of crooked dishonest spending would at least generate something in the Democrats' minds and it does not.

SPEECH.PARA: We are proud to stand in front of the Australian people and say we would not bring down a government over such a grovelling and grubby issue which the Opposition itself, after the event, has had its hands in and is embarrassed by. TALK.START.PARA: —You've got your chance on the vote.

—I am saying it now. Senator Macdonald asked me to stand up and say what our position is. I am saying that we are proud not to be a party to a proposition to block Supply and bring down the Government over postal abuse, of which the Opposition, I believe, will be proven to be the masters and the gold medal winner. —Senator McLean, I ask you to address your remarks through the chair.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter comes down to the fact that people who live in glass houses should not throw blunt instruments; it is as simple as that. The Opposition will be overwhelmed by embarrassment, I believe, as time goes on. I am staggered by the fact that the Opposition could bring this issue before the chamber today. Mr Chairman, I do not resile in the slightest from saying that the Democrats will not be a party to the process of blocking Supply on an issue which was grubby in the beginning and which the Opposition has rendered even more grubby now.

The Government will reject the request, send it back to us and so on. So we have Supply stalled and/or blocked, according to the way it is interpreted, in this place. Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why was the decision on the assets test changed? The decision has nothing to do with all those petitions which went around country Australia and the Opposition back bench going into the party meeting and saying, `Listen, we are losing votes in the bush on the question of the assets test on family allowance'. Who was the Opposition losing its votes to? Honourable senators should read the report in the Australian Financial Review.
—Certainly not to you.
—Senator Mac- donald, you are not at a shire council meeting now.

—The Opposition was not losing its votes to the Government, whose initiative this was, and which, under normal circumstances, on its record on Budget Bills, it would be expected to support. It was its right to do that in a democratic situation, but it did not look good in the media. SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition wants an election before its Leader gets rolled many more times and before the honeymoon starts to end. Fair enough. That is its political right. All we are saying is that we do not support the Opposition in this political exercise. We are not saying that we do not support it on the principle of the grubby business of the stamps, to quote my colleague; we are just saying that this is a political exercise in which the Opposition is engaging. When the Opposition announced it publicly, it told the public via the media that it would take it to the point of blocking Supply. We are not prepared to do that. That is the simple fact of the matter and it does not require all of the time that it has taken in the chamber.

I will now respond to the second thing that Senator Michael Baume asked about. As to the interjection in which he heard me say, `We put pensioners above that' I do not know how much of that will have been recorded by Hansard because there were a great many interjections being made at the time. Among those was the very issue being canvassed across the chamber-in a quite disorderly way, I will admit, and with the indulgence of the Chair at the time. Included in that crossfire engaged in were references to the political stunt that was going on. It was in that context that I said, `We put pensioners above that'. We put pensioners above the political exercise and we have done so all along. I do not speak just about pensioners; I speak also of the welfare of the people of this community. That is why over the years that those opposite have been in opposition we have attempted to amend Government Bills, Budget Bills and money Bills. We have not attempted to amend Supply Bills. In this instance where the Opposition is exercising its proper right to do that, which we do not deny, we are not going to support it, because we have always gone to the public saying we will not block Supply.

As I said, we have put many initiatives before this chamber over the years to amend government legislation. Very few of them have been supported by the Opposition. The consequence has been that the Opposition has voted again and again with the Government. For some reason, Senator Macdonald seems to be implying that we vote with the Government all the time. That is not the case and the record shows it. It is the consequences of Senator Short's motion that we oppose. That is the reason we will not support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say a few words, largely in relation to remarks that have been made by the Australian Democrats, but also to make one or two other comments about the opinion that the Government has received and which Senator Bolkus seems to take great comfort from. Firstly, I refer to some remarks by Senator Powell and Senator McLean, who seem to be somewhat confused as to what I was supposed to have said. It is not very clear to me exactly what allegation Senator McLean is making, but it is certainly not the case that I have ever said, publicly or privately, that it was the Opposition's intention and purpose in this exercise to bring the Government down or force an election. It was clearly spelt out by me that that was not the Opposition's intention. We were moving a reduction in this expenditure for the purpose of keeping the Government honest-using the phrase that the Democrats rather colourfully use. That was their purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: At all times I have made our purpose perfectly clear. I can only assume that was at the press conference, because I never had any discussion with Senator McLean. He was raving on in such an emotional way, it was difficult to understand what he was saying, but I had no discussion with him or with any Democrat about the matter. The only discussions I am aware of were those that took place between the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) and Senator Powell, to which I was not a party. They are not in discussion here. Senator Powell has not mentioned them, and that is fair enough.

I simply rise to reject this notion that it has been the Opposition's intention to bring the Government down. The Opposition's intention has been to require the Government to account for the $1m it unlawfully and illegally spent out of last year's Budget and which it does not intend, apparently, to try even to recoup in this Budget. I want to know what the Democrats say should be done about the $1m misappropriated by the Government. The Opposition's position is clear. It is seeking to have the Government account for that, and the only way it can do so is to move that the Government's Budget be reduced by $1m. The fact is that if the Democrats had supported that, which would be consistent with their whole stance on the matter, the Government simply would have acceded to it and would have reduced its Budget by $1m. There would never have been any sort of Supply crisis, or blocking of Supply, or whatever colourful language the Democrats, the Press Gallery or Senator Bolkus want to use. In fact, the phrase `blocking Supply' is one of popular manufacture--

TALK.START.PARA: —A total red herring.

—It is a total red herring, as Senator Short says. What I intended to say when I got up to speak was that the High Court of Australia made it perfectly clear in a judgment that there is no magic about a Supply Act as such. The High Court says that, under modern parliamentary practice, a Supply Act is simply an Appropriation Act. The person it quoted as the authority for this proposition was none other than Mr Justice Evatt, as he then was. Later he became the Leader of the Australian Labor Party. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In truth the modern Supply Acts . . . are not merely Supply Acts but also Appropriation Acts so far as they operate and extend. The constitutional practice is that such Acts are subsequently embodied in one Appropriation Act . . .

The word Supply is one, as I said, of popular manufacture and it is time that honourable senators started using the appropriate constitutional language as to what is in issue here. There is certainly no magic about an Appropriation Bill, as far as the Senate's powers are concerned, and there never has been. There is simply a restriction on whether the Senate can amend certain types of Appropriation Bills. In fact, if the Senate cannot amend them, it can request an amendment and, of course, it can always oppose it. It is a very technical distinction between amending a Bill and requesting an amendment to a Bill. In modern parliamentary practice, it is quite a distinction without a difference. There is a constitutional provision about it, and that is why we do it this way. As far as Appropriation Bills and taxation Bills are concerned, both of which are referred to as money Bills in general terms--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about those two?

— I am more interested in what I am saying than in worrying about what the Minister is doing. There is no magic about the Appropriation Bills, as such, because two-thirds of the revenue of a modern government comes from appropriations in countless legislation. I would just like to point out to Senator Powell that the Parliamentary Entitlements Act-Senator Parer's amendment to which Senator Michael Baume and Senator Lees supported-is an Appropriation Act. After all the benefits are set out in the schedule, section 11 states:

SPEECH.PARA: 11. The costs of benefits are to be paid out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund, which is appropriated accordingly.

Senator Powell supported the amendment to that Bill. She has supported amendments to numerous Appropriation Bills and numerous taxation Bills. It is the height of hypocrisy for the Australian Democrats to come in here and act holier than thou about the fact that this is an Appropriation Bill. They had better go back and study these matters a bit more carefully before they make these sorts of statements in the chamber. As I have already pointed out, the Government will shortly use this procedure to amend a Bill which appropriates money for pensions and social services when it amends its own legislation about the assets test.

There is nothing magical about this being an Appropriation Bill. Senator Michael Baume mentioned the Guilfoyle principle. The Opposition laid down that general policy approach some years ago. It was expressed by Senator Guilfoyle when she was, I think, shadow Minister for Finance and when she represented the shadow Treasurer in this chamber. She announced that the Opposition would follow generally the principle that the Government should get its Budget every year, except in exceptional circumstances. That has always been the Opposition's reservation. We regard this case as exceptional and that is why we are taking this action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make only a few points. I was really surprised to hear the previous speaker, Senator Durack, say that no approaches were made-they were his words-to the Australian Democrats to discuss with us this important matter, the consequences of which could be very far-reaching, as has been pointed out by several of my colleagues.
—I said that I hadn't spoken to them. You didn't even listen to what I just said a minute ago.
—I did listen. I came back into the chamber to hear Senator Durack's remarks. He said that no approaches were made to discuss this very important matter with the Democrats.
—By me.

—By Senator Durack; he has been very stoutly defending this action. Let me refer to the two honourable senators with the Scottish names-Senator Campbell and Senator Macdonald. The Scots have a reputation for being very concerned about money matters. They have proved their stodginess and their concern about money in the way in which they have addressed this matter. We are dealing with an amount of just over $1m. The Opposition has been at great pains to point out that a High Court decision has been given in this matter and that therefore certain action should automatically follow.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague Senator Powell has pointed out, but I must reiterate, that more often than not the Opposition has sided with the Government on very important matters involving the expenditure of money in the area of welfare and social justice for Australians. The principle of the rights of the most disadvantaged in our community is very important to us. I would like to highlight just a couple of occasions on which the Opposition has crossed the floor and voted with the Government. Coalition members have sat virtually cheek by jowl with the Government senators-in their laps-in support of matters which involved the expenditure of money to help the most disadvantaged people in this community.

On several occasions I have sat in this chamber when the Democrats have proposed removing the sales tax on wheelchairs. We have moved on a number of occasions for the removal of sales tax on computers to be used by disadvantaged children for educational purposes. On every single occasion the Opposition has voted against those proposals by the Democrats and has gone across and voted with the Government. Surely the principle that underlies those sorts of decisions to provide modest amounts of money to the most disadvantaged people in the community is more important than simply accepting a High Court decision, no matter how uniform and how technically correct that decision may have been, simply because it is a High Court decision.

A great deal has been said of a certain former member of the Opposition ranks. The situation is quite clear: over a certain period there was expenditure at a certain rate-expenditure presumably for legitimate electorate purposes for which the postal allowance is made. Suddenly, just before an election, that expenditure accelerated to an enormous level. A figure of $100,000 in one day has been mentioned. We are asked to believe that that expenditure was legitimately incurred for electorate purposes. This same group of senators who belong to that same Party are asking us to vote here on a matter concerning $1m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it illegal? Has it been found illegal? Address your mind to the principle.

— I thank Senator Michael Baume for that interjection. It precisely makes the point that the narrow technical principle is far more important than the justice and the morality that lie behind the action. Senator Baume has defended the action of his former colleague Mr Blunt in that expenditure because technically it might have been legitimate. That is precisely the point the Democrats are making--
—Don't you understand the difference between legal and illegal behaviour?
—I thank the Opposition for its interjections. I am asked whether I understand the difference between legal and moral.

—Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. The Minister is not in the chamber. I notice that he has now come back in. I think it would help this debate were the Minister to remain seated at his desk and listen to the matters that are being raised.
—Senator Kemp, that is not a point of order, and you know it is not.

—Again, I thank the Opposition for its interjections. The interjection asked whether I understand the difference between `legally correct' and `morally correct'. Yes, I certainly do. That is precisely the distinction I am making. There are occasions when the legal technicality is far less important--
—So you are the judge and jury?

—I again thank Senator Baume for his interjection. We are indeed the judge and jury. We are elected to the highest court in this land to make decisions about the expenditure of money for the welfare of the Australian community, and Opposition senators regularly vote with the Government to disadvantage some of the most disadvantaged people in this community because technically that is what they believe and legally they believe it is correct to do that. That is not our position. We believe that morally we should protect the interests of those people. That is why, among other reasons, we are not supporting this narrow, technical move by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has also made great play of the claim that this is not a move towards a possible election. Yet Senator Macdonald himself used half of his speech to describe how he had raced out this morning to get the latest copy of the Bulletin to look at the results and then in front of this chamber paraded the results of the public opinion poll as to the support for the Opposition. That took up half of his speech in a debate about this matter on postage.

It would seem that the Opposition by its own actions has established that what lies behind this move is an attempt to take advantage of this temporary respite in its fall from favour to grab an opportunity to cause an election, if that is possible. As opposition senators would know, that could be an outcome of this move. It will not be because we will not support the Opposition's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will cut them off at the pass.
—As my colleague Senator Powell said, we will cut them off at the pass.
—Rightly or wrongly, legally or illegally.

—There we have another interjection-`rightly or wrongly'. We are making a judgment as to the correctness and the comprehensive morality of the move being made. We see the Opposition's move as a pragmatic attempt, an unprincipled attempt, simply to grab power at this stage, and we will not support it. We will not support this amendment at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that there are other members of the coalition still to speak, so I thank my coalition colleagues for their support in the amendment that I have moved on behalf of the Opposition. I refer particularly to the contributions by Senator Durack, Senator Parer, Senator Walters, Senator Kemp, Senator Michael Baume and Senator Macdonald. I would like also to thank Senator Harradine for his contribution, which I thought was extraordin- arily good and lucid and on which I congratulate him.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go on to the couple of comments I want to make, I would just pick up Senator Coulter's last remarks about the question of whether we are trying to force an election. It is a similar sort of point to the one that Senator Powell was making. If I understood her correctly, she said that the Australian Democrats are not supporting this amendment because of its possible consequences, namely, the blocking of Supply. Are the Australian Democrats really serious in saying that if the Government wants its Budget--

TALK.START.PARA: —Its appropriations.

—Its appropriations-it is going to refuse to accept a request from the Parliament to reduce its appropriations by $1m in the Department of Administrative Services, the budget for which this year is $445m, the Government's total appropriations being $90,000m? Are the Democrats seriously suggesting that the Government would not accept a request for a reduction of $1m out of a total expense of $90,000m? That just defies comprehension and is quite obviously not the reason why the Democrats are not supporting this motion. They are not supporting the motion because they are in the pockets of the Government, of the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition's actions may be seen by some as essentially symbolic because a million dollars, as I have said, is a very small amount of money in the context of the Government's Budget of $90,000m, and it is small even in the context of the appropriations of the Department of Administrative Services of $445m. But to most people a million dollars is a lot of money, particularly in the recessed Australia of today-an Australia that has been recessed as a result of the policies of this Government; a Government that says average Australians must pull in their belts and accept lower living standards while still paying exorbitant levels of taxation to a Government which spends without inhibition, even if that spending is illegal and unconstitutional, as is the case in the present instance.

But it is also much more than symbolism. What is at stake here, as has been pointed out by several speakers on this side of the chamber, is a basic matter of principle. The Government and the Democrats today have thrown principle out of the window. They have shown their true colours. They have ignored principle. They are paying no regard to the law or to the Constitution by refusing to accept this amendment. They pay no regard to the basic rights of taxpayers who expect this Government, their Government, only to spend their taxpayers' dollars legally. That is what this is about.

The Government and the Democrats will stand condemned before the electorate for this decision today-condemned by their own actions in failing to support the amendment and by their comments in this debate. This debate and this amendment are about honesty. The Government has acted dishonestly; it has acted illegally. The Committee does not need me, and the Government does not need me, to tell them that. The High Court, by unanimous decision, has said so. Even the Government apparently agrees with the High Court judgment that the decision is illegal.

While we are discussing matters of basic principle, the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) parades around this chamber like a peacock. Having just read the newspapers and having left the chamber for several minutes, he is not paying one iota of attention to a matter which goes to the very basis of democratic parliamentary government. The failure to accept the coalition amendment will mean, in effect, that this Parliament will be acting in contempt of the High Court. That is what this will mean. Certainly it will be acting against the spirit of the High Court.

Not only is this matter about honesty and legality and observance of the views of the highest court in this land; it is also about integrity, and integrity seems to be a word that this Government and the Democrats have forgotten all about. It is also about propriety and the rights of citizens to expect parliamentary standards which incorporate these qualities, which are essential for the continued functioning of any democratic parliamentary system.

That, let me say again, is what the coalition's amendment is all about. That is why its acceptance by the Parliament is so important: to demonstrate to an understandably and increasingly cynical electorate that the Parliament still adheres to certain basic standards, including in particular respect for the law and the Constitution of this nation. That is what this amendment is about. It will be a very sad day indeed when, as appears likely, this chamber votes against this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope in speaking to conclude this particular debate. In doing so, I wish to make a couple of points. I think it is fair to say that this has been, in terms of its timing, one of the most irrelevant debates that this chamber has had to go through. It is also fair to say that, for those who might be listening to it, it has become the `flogging the dead horse' debate. I think those terms that were used by Senator Powell in the early stages of this event are quite appropriate to what we are going through now.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has been subjected to more than 3 1/2 hours of debate on this issue. If a figure can be put on it, it must have cost the Australian taxpayer about three-quarters of a million dollars for us to go through what is a fruitless exercise-an exercise that the Opposition knew was fruitless from the start. The taxpayer has to ask, `For what purpose?'. This was a political farce from the moment Senator Durack tried to walk out of a press conference. As I said last night, in Inspector Clouseau fashion, he kept on walking into cupboards and doors that would lead nowhere. There was great embarrassment.

It was a political farce, as has been highlighted here today, from the time of the announcement that the Opposition would try to stop or stall Appropriation Bill (No. 1). Members of the Opposition had not done their homework; they had not contacted the Australian Democrats. It was a political farce from the moment that the Democrats made it very clear that they thought this was flogging a dead horse. This farce exposed the inadequacy of the coalition when the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), when confronted with the question from the media, `Aren't you stopping or stalling Supply?', could not give an answer. This farce has exposed the irrelevance of the Opposition and the incompetence and inadequacy of young Dr Hewson. The Opposition is driven, as I said last night, by the same forces-the ghosts of 1975. Members of the Opposition thought it was a great trick at the time but they cannot do it twice and they cannot do it in respect of something such as this.

In this debate members of the Opposition have exposed their lack of homework, their lack of competence and, as I said last night, their irrelevance. They are fiddling at the fringes. As time goes by during this Government's term of office, those opposite will be more and more exposed as being preoccupied at the fringes but not being able to tackle the big issues confronting Australia. That is what is coming out. Those opposite must think seriously about it. They sat here laughing this time last year and before the 1986 election. But the reality is that when they went to the election last year they had not tackled the big issues; they were not big enough to grapple with them.

That has been exposed again by their concentration on this issue and their lack of adequacy to confront the issue that they think is the most important one-that is, cutting government expenditure. It is very easy to come in here and make political speeches about issues such as this. Even Senator Walters can do that. But when it comes to cutting back even $30m or $40m-the Opposition has a program to cut back $3 billion-its Leader cannot carry the weight. He has not got the strength, the political fortitude or the adequacy. Members of the Opposition might as well stay with these issues which they think they might be getting something out of-and for a while they were. But it has been a long time since this issue has been an important one out in the electorate. The electorate is concerned about other matters; it is about time those opposite woke up to it.

Another way in which members of the Opposition have exposed their inadequacy is the way they have tackled the legal issues related to this matter. They have come in here and said, `The Government has acted illegally; it is illegal'. They have spread the word around Goebbels-like in the expectation that people might attach something to it. But, as I explained last night, in what was probably a short lesson on justice, the law and the process of courts, it is not uncommon for State or Federal governments in this country to have their legislation, regulations or administrative action ruled ultra vires. That is what has happened here. No-one disputes that. We know that.

What did the Government do after that? We sought advice from the highest authority available to us, the Solicitor-General, as to whether we could recover. That was not mentioned at all by the Opposition. The advice was that it was very clear that the moneys were irrecoverable either from Australia Post or from individual senators or members.

If those opposite are to understand the issue at stake, if they are going to be honest enough and comprehensive enough to tackle the issue at stake, they have to accept that point. They have not. They have gone off and used the buzz word `illegality', which is totally inappropriate. They are stuck on that. What the Government will do in this matter, what it has done in this matter and what it will do in other matters before it is seek the same sort of advice and, if we can recover, we will. We have been told we cannot.

This debate has been irrelevant. To the extent that it has been relevant to anyone, once again it has exposed the fact that the Opposition is in a time warp. We can understand why it is in a time warp. As I said last night, it has a worse batting line-up-both in this chamber and the other-than the English 11. At least the English have a captain, an opening batsman and a good bowler or two. But the mob opposite, the pretenders to government, as they have been for almost all of the last decade, cannot take the heat. As I said last night, they are playing in the nets while the rest of society is playing on the main pitch. To that extent, let me say also that it is not just the Government that recognises the concerns of the electorate at the moment; it is good to see the Democrats also showing a greater degree of competence and intelligence than has been shown by the Opposition.

This matter has been useful to the extent that it has exposed the Opposition. As I have said, to every other extent it has been a `flogging a dead horse' debate. But let me also say that it has cost the Australian taxpayer probably three-quarters of a million dollars. It has been a fruitless waste of money.
