—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the significance of last week's Paris meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, can the Minister comment on agreements reached at that meeting on the reduction of conventional forces in Europe (CFE)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government very warmly welcomes the signature of the historic CFE agreement at the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe summit on 19 November. The CFE agreement is the most ambitious arms control treaty ever achieved and the first conventional arms control treaty since the Second World War to include both the superpowers. It strengthens the new political order in Europe by establishing the upper limits of the military forces of the 22 nations that are covered by the treaty. This codifies the security gains that have been made as a result of the dramatic changes that have taken place in the European political order.

ANSWER.PARA: The agreement sets limits for each group of parties, that is, North Atlantic Treaty Organisation and Eastern countries, to 20,000 tanks, 20,000 artillery pieces, 30,000 armoured combat vehicles, 2,000 attack helicopters and 6,800 combat aircraft each.

Agreement was reached on the proportion of forces in each alliance that any single country can station in Europe-that is, the so-called self-sufficiency rule. This ensures that no one country covered by the treaty can maintain more than roughly one-third of the limits set in each of those five categories of equipment that I have mentioned. Military equipment in excess of the limits established is to be destroyed. A limited exception allows each side to convert 750 tanks and 3,000 armoured combat vehicles to civilian use.

In addition to on-site monitoring of destruction, the agreement has provision for effective verification, including detailed information exchange, on-site inspection of military facilities and challenge inspections. A joint consultative group has been established so that questions relating to compliance and implementation can be discussed.

There are a number of additional political commitments outside the CFE agreement which have been made. Germany is committed to limit its manpower to 370,000, of which no more than 345,000 will be ground and air forces. Each signatory is committed not to increase its ground and air personnel levels and each group of parties is committed to limit its land based naval aircraft to 430, with no more than 400 in any one country. The parties to the CFE have also agreed to begin follow-on negotiations to the CFE. These talks are expected to cover areas such as personnel, aerial inspections and stabilisation measures.

The Government strongly supports the efforts of the United States and the Soviet Union to build a more stable global security environment and it hopes that the CFE agreement will provide impetus for further progress in arms control and disarmament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer to yesterday's announcement by the chairperson of the Australian War Memorial Council that from 1 January 1991 an entrance fee will be charged for admission to the Australian War Memorial. I ask the Minister: can the Government not see the sickening irony that wars and the preparation for war are financed from the public purse, yet our national monument to our war dead is starved of dollars to the point where its administration feels it essential to charge admission? In view of the abhorrence of the public, and especially the veterans, to this decision, will the Government take the necessary action to prevent this crass and disrespectful commercialism?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator McLean, I want to very adamantly reject the notion that the Australian War Memorial is being starved of funds by the Australian Federal Government. Indeed, this financial year, I understand the Government has appropriated some $16m to the memorial. I believe this is a very considerable sum, but well justified in supporting the activities of the Australian War Memorial Council. That funding of $16m includes money to go towards the first stage of the construction of a new exhibition hall. That is an example of the way in which the Federal Government, through its funding, is supporting the extended activities of the War Memorial.

ANSWER.PARA: No doubt all institutions would like to see more funding, but that is not always possible. It is against that background that the War Memorial Council came to the decision to introduce a charge. I want to repeat and make very clear to the chamber that it was the War Memorial Council that decided on implementing this charge, and not the Government. I believe I am right in recalling that that Council is headed by Dame Beryl Beaurepaire, a woman held in very high regard from all sides of the Australian community and politics. I believe she has come to a very defensible decision in this matter. It would not be open to the Government to try to reverse that decision under the autonomy and independence guaranteed to the War Memorial Council in its Act. I am sure the ex-service community-which Senator McLean professes to be concerned about-would not wish that particular section in the War Memorial Act to be altered in any way.

It has to be emphasised that the charge for entrance, which the War Memorial Council has determined, applies only to the exhibition halls; it does not relate to those more sacred spaces, if you like, within the War Memorial: the courtyard; the Roll of Honour; and the Hall of Memory. The charge is small, $3 for adults, with a concessional charge of $2 for Australian war veterans and pensioners. Children will be free, in line with the Memorial's main education objectives. Of course, on Anzac Day and Remembrance Day, entry will be free to all visitors.

When we consider the very small magnitude of those charges I believe we see very readily that Australians and overseas visitors who visit the Memorial will find it a very small payment indeed for the many hours of absolute fascination and almost literal entrancement that one has when one wanders around those exhibitions with no sense of time at all. One can easily spend a day there for $2 or $3, understanding better the history of Australia's service men and women in their various conflicts overseas. I believe that is a very small fee to pay for that very wonderful experience.

I believe that most veterans understand why this was necessary. The extra funding generated will enhance the exhibitions and the collections of the War Memorial and make them available to present and future generations in a way which is not possible now despite the very generous funding of $16m per year. I believe all Australians will support the decision by the War Memorial Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I sense that the Minister is suggesting that the Government supports the principle of commercialism in relation to war memorials and museums. Certainly, whether or not the Government supports it, it has been applied by the Council which administers the Memorial. Having recently visited war graves and memorials in Flanders as a member of a parliamentary delegation, and found that a very moving experience, I ask the Minister whether, on my next visit to Australian war graves in Europe and Flanders, I am likely to find them fenced and be confronted with an admission charge?

—Obviously, the answer is no because of the very exception which I pointed to in relation to the charge which is proposed for the War Memorial, namely, that the more sacred areas, which, in fact, include the Roll of Honour, and those areas where we would want to meditate on perhaps relatives or those fellow Australians who died in previous conflicts are accessible at all times completely free of charge. I am sure that that same principle would apply to the war graves which are so well maintained in all parts of the world on behalf of all Australians.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Is he aware of controversy surrounding the alleged harmful effects of urocanic acid in some cosmetic products? Is there any substance to such concerns, and what is the Government doing about them? Is anything going to be done to allow consumers to be informed about the ingredients in cosmetics and their effects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as the presence of urocanic acid in some cosmetics is concerned-and I have no evidence of which cosmetics might contain this particular ingredient-the Committee on Toxicity of the National Health and Medical Research Council is meeting on 14 and 15 December to consider the particular allegations that have been made surrounding this ingredient. I believe that it would be very prudent to await the decision of that Committee before I take any action. I will look to its advice on that matter in mid-December.

ANSWER.PARA: Today I have been able to announce that from now on consumers of cosmetic products in Australia will have the benefit of mandatory full ingredient disclosure on the labels of various cosmetic products which they purchase. I believe that this is going to be extremely acceptable to all consumers, not only from the point of view of protecting themselves from skin irritants and allergies which may be occasioned by an unknown ingredient in a particular cosmetic, but also, of course, in that it will enable them to go into the marketplace and compare those products which perhaps have very similar listings of ingredients but are packaged and marketed in different ways. Sometimes it is the mere packaging which leads to an increase in price. From the point of view of both the skin and purse of the purchaser, he or she will be well served by this provision.

Full ingredient labelling, a notice on the product of the country of origin, a use by date where the product might deteriorate in less than 30 months, the stating of the Australian manufacturer's or importer's address, the batch code number, and a warning if, for example, the product might be an irritant if placed close to the eye-those sorts of informative labels are very much required by Australian consumers out in the marketplace.

We are talking about an industry which sells $30m worth of products every week. I believe that this industry can well afford, and is cooperating in making available, these labels. The Cosmetic Toiletry and Fragrance Association of Australia and the Royal College of Dermatologists are both very strongly supporting this initiative. I believe that with that support we will be able to ensure that within 12 months there will be 100 per cent compliance within this mandatory cosmetic full ingredient disclosure. I believe that that is going to be to the great benefit of all consumers in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. The Minister will be aware that the Australian Taxation Office has been seeking since 1985 to tax leasing incentives given to tenants and that this approach was recently upheld in the High Court in the so-called Cooling case. I ask the Minister why the Australian Property Group, when seeking space on behalf of Federal governments, includes in its tender requirements rent-free periods and up-front cash payments, the latter being for office space for the Tax Office. How prevalent has this Government practice been for the last five years? Given that the Commonwealth Government does not pay tax, is this yet another example of the Labor Government's double standards?

—We get some curious questions and this is another one. Senator Parer last night in the Committee of the Whole talked about the imperatives of making the trust account operations within the Department of Administrative Services operate on a commercial basis. The Australian Property Group has been competing in the marketplace for rental or owned space. In the marketplace, the provision of rent-free periods and other benefits is very much in practice. The question of taxability thereof accrues and, as he rightly said, in view of the recent court decision, will apply. —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. It has been estimated that a lack of sufficient literacy skills in the workplace now costs Australia approximately $3.2 billion a year in the additional time taken to communicate instructions. I ask the Minister: what is the Government doing to address problems of literacy within industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Aulich for his question. He has, through his involvement in committees in this place and elsewhere, shown a great degree of interest in this area. As honourable senators would or should know, the Government has maintained a substantial contribution to implementing the aims of the International Literacy Year. Recently the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, announced a package of about $40m over the next three years to continue the work already begun in 1990. In that package was an additional amount of $4.5m for each of the next three years for adult literacy training through appropriate State authorities. Also as part of the package, we will be maintaining existing funding through vocational education and literacy programs. Nearly $1.3m will be available for adult literacy courses in technical and further education, for instance, next year. A further $1.6m will also be available to non-government adult education providers. The bulk of these funds, it is expected, will be directed to adult literacy.

ANSWER.PARA: We recognise that there is a problem. There is undeniable evidence that poor communication skills adversely affect productivity in the workplace. The problems emanating from them include inconsistent product quality, excessive wastage of products, failure to meet product quality standards, damage to equipment, injuries and so on. All of these difficulties, singly and collectively, obviously inhibit our capacity to be competitive in world export markets.

As one measure taken by the Government last month in Melbourne, we held the first literacy in industry conference, bringing together for the first time representatives of industry trainers and managers, both of whom are crucial in improving the level of literacy skills across a wide range of industries. This week in Sydney, Mr Dawkins also opened the second of these national conferences, a conference aiming firstly to improve the relationship between productivity and a literate and numerate work force; secondly, to provide strategies for improving and utilising workers' literacy and numeracy skills; and, thirdly, to analyse the implications of structural efficiency principles and award restructuring in industries where workers do not have adequate literacy and numeracy skills.

The conference is targeted towards specific industries, including the public sector, metals, electrical, tourism, plastics and retail. The other important part of this particular conference is that participants have been drawn from managers, employers, training personnel, union officials and representatives of industry training councils.

Together with that, the Government is producing an information kit entitled `Literacy Training: the Key to Long Term Productivity'. It is designed specifically for the corporate sector, providing business people with information about the value of improving literacy training in businesses. Thirdly, literacy and language training can also qualify as eligible expenditure under the training guarantee. We also recognise the importance of transmitting information to employees in plain English. For example, an Australian study based on compensation payouts estimated that the total cost for employment injuries attributed to poor English is between $10m and $30m.

One aspect of handling this particular problem is to change the forms that emanate both from government and from industry. For instance, over $400,000 a year in staff time was saved in the Victorian Attorney-General's Department after rewriting and redesigning just one summons form. Just to indicate the level of the financial savings that can be made, in Britain the Department of Health and Social Security rewrote its legal forms at a cost of about $30,000 and it then recouped $2m in just one year. The Government's future activities in this area--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on. This is a speech.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, this is a very long answer and I would ask you to conclude it.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask that the Minister table the document from which he has read every word of his answer which illustrates that this was not a question without notice, and that it in fact could have been a statement incorporated fully instead of wasting the time of the Senate.

—I will speak to that point of order, Mr President. It is about time we put on the record in response to the point of order raised by the honourable senator opposite that there are many occasions in this place when dorothy dixers are not asked-notice is possibly given beforehand-by backbenchers who are very interested in an issue, and we do not intend to have our place in this Parliament in any way put aside by the Opposition. —I will not, and in conclusion I just make two points. First of all, our future activity in this area will depend and emanate from our Green Paper on literacy and language which will be released before Christmas. Can the Minister for Administrative Services advise why he has put the brakes on the reform process in the Australian Construction Services (ACS) by instructing his Department to stop any further rationalisation planned in an endeavour to streamline the work force? Is the Minister aware that it is the view of his Department that he is frustrating its efforts to properly commercialise the programs within his Department? From where does he expect the additional cost savings to come in order to offset the cost of retaining people in positions which have been identified as being redundant?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Herron was not here last night for the consideration of Estimates. Had he been here he would have understood that what is happening in the Department of Administrative Services is a progressive moving towards trust accounts and commercialisation of the operations. One cannot do that overnight and in fact the trust account operation to which he refers is one going through a transition period at the moment. In view of that and as part of the transition period, there is a substantial degree of untying which has already been announced by Government-untying meaning that the Australian Construction Services will not have tied government clients as a normal practice. As a consequence of that, it is anticipated that there will be a decrease in workload, at least for an interim period. ANSWER.PARA: Also as part of this, the restructuring and commercialisation process is, and should be, going on in cooperation with the relevant trade unions involved. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters. Is it a fact that ratification by the Government of International Labour Organisation (ILO) Convention 159 obliges Australia to carry out a number of policies to assist the vocational rehabilitation and employment of people with disabilities? Does this obligation apply particularly to the Australian Government as the leading employer in the country? Can the Minister advise the Senate of what actions the Government is taking and planning to take regarding the employment conditions of people with disabilities in the Australian Public Service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Senate knows, this Government is committed to the principle of social justice for all Australians. In support of that general principle, in 1983 the Government issued a policy paper entitled Reforming the Public Service and committed itself to `equality of employment opportunity that gives all Australian citizens the chance to compete equally on merit for entry into the Australian Public Service'. In the terms of its own employment responsibilities, in 1984 the Government amended the Public Service Act to require agencies to implement equal employment opportunity (EEO) programs for, amongst others, people with physical disabilities and intellectual disabilities. The Government has also recently upgraded the status of the senior position within the Public Service Commission which is responsible for the promotion and continued development and implementation of EEO policies in the Australian Public Service.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government announced on 10 August that it had ratified ILO Convention No. 159-that is, the Convention entitled `Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (Disabled Workers) 1983'-which provides for the adoption of a new international standard in relation to the employment of people with disabilities. The Convention requires that countries adopt and implement policies on vocational rehabilitation and employment of people with disabilities, and provide guidance, training and placement opportunities for them.

In pursuit of its social justice policies, the Government announced in the recent Budget a major income support related reform package that seeks to provide people with disabilities with much better opportunity to become active in the work force and the wider community. Building on this initiative, in the Australian Public Service the Public Service Commission has taken the lead to improve the recruitment and retention of people with disabilities in the service through two separate programs: the extension of the intellectual disability access program (IDAP), which is a program for people with intellectual disabilities, who will be considered for appointment on individual merit rather than having to compete in the standard selection process; and the development of a service-wide information strategy promoting the focus on ability. The IDAP extension and the resource material were launched on 23 October by the Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Brian Howe.

I conclude by saying that recent employment statistics for the Australian Public Service show that 7 per cent of Australian Public Service staff are identified as persons with some disability or other.

—Did the Minister for Industrial Relations take part in discussions this morning with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) executive? Did these discussions include the issue of the tax-wage trade-off agreed to last week between the Government and the ACTU? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the outcome of those discussions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the first two questions are yes and yes. As the Senate will know, under accord mark 6 the first wage increase for 1990 is to be based on the September quarter consumer price index. Yesterday the ACTU executive meeting in Melbourne adopted the officers' recommendation to accept the Government proposal on the wage-tax trade-off, that is, substituting a tax cut for the September quarter wage increase. Earlier there was a suggestion that the officers of the ACTU might call a special unions conference to further endorse the executive decision. Given the views of its affiliates, the executive was unanimous that that was not necessary. There will now be no special unions conference. Therefore, accord mark 6A, as it has been styled, or 6 1/2 or 6(i)-the new accord-is now official and it has been adopted by both the Government and the ACTU.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the content of the new accord, previously it had been announced that the second wage increase to follow the September quarter was to be a $12 across the board increase to be paid six months after the operative date of the first increase. Today we have agreed with the ACTU to put an actual operative date on when that $12 will be paid. That operative date will be 16 May next year.

The Industrial Relations Commission has announced the calling of a national wage case, which will convene in Melbourne on Monday. It will commence its proceedings with submissions from the ACTU. The Australian Government will appear later next week and we will put our submissions. Given the timetabling of the national wage case, our hope that there would be a national wage case decision before Christmas may now not be realised as logistically it may not be possible for the hearings to be completed in time for a decision to be brought down. But whether it is before Christmas or early in the new year, I believe the point that we are concerned should be held to is that very early in the commencement of calendar 1991 the wages outlook for the whole of that year will be clear, settled and predictable. That will mean that employers can plan their budgets and strategies against a settled background of wages policy and a clear perspective of what outcomes will be over the course of calendar 1991.

Yesterday I said that the wage-tax trade-off means that middle and low income earners do slightly better than they would have done had they received their wage increases. I demonstrated that by resorting to examples of $20,000, $25,000 and $30,000. I said yesterday as well that the tax trade-off gives a better quality money improvement for ordinary workers in the sense that it will not impose costs on industry. Thus, it will not have the impact on prices that a wage increase would have. As well, I have said that effectively we now have a 12 months wages pause, from March this year to May next year; that our inflation target of 6 per cent, as set out in the Budget, will be realised, if not undershot; and that Australia's inflation is now of course trending downwards, when inflation levels in all Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development economies are going up. That puts us in a much more beneficial trading position. I have also said that we have revised our aggregate wage outcome for the year--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: tedious repetition is against the Standing Orders. The Minister has told us that he is repeating what he said yesterday; he has told us that in the last five aspects of this answer. I therefore ask you, Mr President, in light of the Standing Orders to have him sit down.

—Order! In recent days there has been a great improvement in the number of questions that have been asked but, unfortunately, today has not been good. I would remind Senator Cook that he is repeating the answer that he gave yesterday, and I would ask him to conclude as soon as possible.

—I am repeating some elements, Mr President, with respect, in order to make a conclusion. The point is that the aggregate wage outcome set for this Budget of 7 per cent is now revised downwards to 6.25 per cent-an outcome that I thought Senator Hill might in fact support. The other fact is, of course, that the wage-tax trade-off has been universally acclaimed. Therefore, the accord has proven its flexibility and adaptability in changing economic circumstances. If one contrasts it to the Opposition's wages policy, for which there is no international model at all--

—Mr President, on a point of order: I draw your attention to standing order 73(4), which makes it very clear that the Minister shall not debate a question. If the Minister wants to debate the accord at any time, we on this side are happy to do so. It has delivered falling living standards to Australian workers, and if the Minister wants to have that debate let us have it. But, Mr President, you should make him answer the question properly.
—Order! There is no point of order. I ask the Minister to conclude his answer, and I believe that he is doing that.

— I will conclude now, Mr President. I just draw a contrast between our settled, practical and effective wages policy and the bankruptcy of the Opposition. In reply to the last point, living standards for Australian workers have not fallen under the accord at all. That is an Opposition fallacy.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Under what circumstances, if any, is it acceptable for the Minister's Department to advertise to, for example, senators, members and their staff, services offered by private enterprise in Canberra or elsewhere?
—That seems to be such a hypothetical question that Senator Vanstone could probably ask a supplementary question and I will answer that.

—What I basically ask is: does the Minister's Department have guidelines for the advertisement of services of private enterprise to senators, members and their staff, whether the services are offered in Canberra or elsewhere? Since the Minister has invited a supplementary question, I will rephrase the first question and add to it. What does the Statesman Hotel-Motel in Canberra have that makes it so special and allows the Minister's Department to advertise the services of that hotel-motel to senators and members of their staff?
—Stay there and find out.

—I probably cannot do better in answering that question than to repeat what Senator Faulkner said, and that was, `Stay there and find out'. The question is a pretty general one in that it refers to one hotel. I am not so sure if that is not part of a package or whatever. Given the hypothetical nature and the generality of the question, I think it is probably best for me to find out in what context this hotel has in fact been advertised and whether it is part of a general program. As far as I am concerned, there is no wholesale scheme to advertise private sector facilities and services. —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware that United States (US) Rear Admiral William Fogarty yesterday pronounced the blockade of Iraq effective and that a US authority on sanctions, Gary Hufbauer of Georgetown University, is reported as saying that he expected sanctions to work, but that it would take a year for that to happen? Does the Government agree that more time should be allowed for sanctions to work, especially as Iraq's industrial output has already fallen by a reported 40 per cent? What information does the Government have about the impact of sanctions on the health of foreign nationals, Kuwaitis and Iraqis, particularly children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government shares the international consensus that United Nations (UN) sanctions are being effectively implemented against Iraq. I certainly agree with the view that was expressed yesterday by Rear Admiral Fogarty that the multinational naval force operation in which Australia has actively participated has been very effective in enforcing UN sanctions against Iraq. Estimates are that less than 5 per cent of Iraq's pre-invasion oil exports are now getting through, that Iraq's industrial production has fallen by as much as 40 per cent, and that no more than about 10 per cent of usual imports are entering the place.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not seen the remarks that are attributed to Mr Hufbauer, but I am aware of a wide diversity of views among commentators about the time frame which might be required to allow sanctions to exert sufficient pressure to persuade the Iraqi leadership that it must withdraw its forces from Kuwait. The sanctions strategy, of course, remains an important element in international efforts to secure a peaceful resolution to the crisis. As we have repeatedly emphasised, a peaceful solution is much the preferred option. Whether a peaceful solution can be achieved through waiting for sanctions to take effect depends not just on the sanctions physically taking some effect but on the Iraqi Government responding to them in a way which recognises the inexorability of hurt and pain and suffering to its own citizens and drawing the logical conclusion from that. We simply cannot make judgments about when it might be prepared to make that kind of judgment. That is why it now appears that the sanctions strategy needs to be reinforced by a further demonstration of the international community's resolve to bring about an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. It is in that context that the Australian Government supports current moves in the UN Security Council to increase pressure on Iraq by authorising all necessary measures-as the resolution has it-to implement relevant UN Security Council resolutions.

While fine detail about the working of the sanctions is not available, as I have already said, most assessments indicate that they are having a significant effect and that their main impact has been on Iraqi infrastructure and industrial production rather than food or medical supplies. Certain foodstuffs have been rationed to ward off serious shortages and apparently the prices of some products have risen, but otherwise food supplies appear to remain adequate at this stage-including for children and foreign nationals.

Security Council resolution 666 provides a framework for the provision of food under UN auspices if and when the `humanitarian circumstances' exemption to sanctions is determined by the UN Security Council to exist. That has not yet happened. The Iraqi Government has made some allegations about the adverse impact of sanctions on particular vulnerable groups in Iraq, but we view these as really no more than another dimension of Iraq's current propaganda efforts. Iraq has not allowed the International Committee of the Red Cross, other recognised international humanitarian agencies or the UN Secretary-General's special representative to visit Iraq to assess the situation. One would assume that, if there was any credibility at all in these claims that are being made, such visits would of course be allowed.

The point that needs to be made is that Iraq's invasion and occupation have of course resulted in very considerable hardship for the Kuwaitis and foreign nationals trapped in Kuwait. That has absolutely nothing whatsoever to do with the operation of UN sanctions. The Government is also concerned about reports of deteriorating conditions for some of the hostages who are detained at strategic sites. This too has nothing whatever to do with sanctions, but rather is the result of the Iraqi Government's illegal and totally inhumane actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the release today of the September quarter balance of payments and foreign debt figures, which show a serious deterioration in Australia's foreign trade, a further widening of our current account deficit and a $1.7 billion increase in our net foreign debt to its second highest level on record. In light of these alarming statistics, I ask the Minister how he responds to the statement today by the Chairman of the Australian and New Zealand Banking Group, Mr Bridgland, when he said that this last year was probably the harshest economy environment for small and medium sized businesses in Australia since World War II. I ask: what policy changes will the Government now take in view of this further evidence of the ongoing failure of its economy policies? Will the Government now heed the Opposition's urgent call for a mini-Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The quarterly figures for the current account deficit will be seen, I think, more intelligently by Senator Hill and others in the light of the national account figures which will be published tomorrow. In anticipation of an Opposition question tomorrow, I invite him to bide his time in terms of the quarterly current account figures.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as Mr Bridgland has made comments-I have not seen the quotation but Senator Hill has referred to it in his question-saying that many small and medium size businesses have not had such difficulties since the Second World War--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are facing the harshest economic environment since the Second World War, according to Mr Bridgland.

—That was a very helpful interjection because now I have the quotation right. There are all sorts of views about this depending on where one sits. If I were sitting in one of the major banks that lent a lot of money to the high-fliers of the 1980s and lost fortunes, I would be a bit concerned about the economic environment in which I found myself. I suppose it is easy to make that a little more acceptable by saying that small and medium size business has had it pretty difficult too. In terms of small size business in this country, any environment policy induced by this Government has been compounded again and again by the behaviour of the banks, as anybody who knows anything about small business in this country knows. Senator Boswell, who comes in here and interjects about small business--
—You always blame somebody else.

—No, I did not say that. I said that any policy induced environment has been compounded by the behaviour of the banks. I do not retreat from that in respect of small business. Honourable senators opposite can yell their heads off as hard as they like. Some of those who know, such as Senator Crane, for example, will not yell their heads off because they know--
—Interest rates have killed them, and you can die only once.

—And Senator Crichton-Browne ought to know better. For over 18 months in Question Time in the Senate we have been answering questions about the interest rate environment and making the point that in terms of Government strategy it was a course which we felt we had to adopt and one from which we would not retreat because of the necessity to dampen demand in the Australian economy. I repeat: that has been compounded by the behaviour of the banks. I am surprised at Senator Hill waltzing in here seeking to endear himself to some small business constituency and quoting Mr Bridgland, the Chairman of the Westpac Banking Corporation, in support of his case.

ANSWER.PARA: The final part of the question relates to whether the Government will embark upon policy changes as a result of the figures published today or because Mr Bridgland or somebody else has a view about all this. The answer to that question is no. The Government has made quite clear what its policy position will be. The current economic circumstances which are being endured and which are difficult for business at the present time are in part a result of earlier policy decisions, but there is no policy change that the Government can make at present which will alleviate those problems. There are no magic wands. If honourable senators opposite go into the electorate and pretend that there are, they are kidding themselves as well as others.

In respect of the third issue, the mini-Budget, the Government has had mini-Budgets on a number of occasions in its nearly eight years of life. Whether it is appropriate to have a mini-Budget next year will be determined by the Government at the appropriate time, and we will tell honourable senators then.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE DISCUSSIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, is against the background of the pressures on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). Given that the Uruguay Round of world trade talks is scheduled to continue in Brussels next week, can the Minister inform the Senate as to the likelihood of substantial progress being made? Are there proposals to go to the meeting which are aimed at significantly reducing the farm subsidies being offered by European Community (EC) countries? Does the Australian Government believe that the talks will lead to a better international environment for trade in Australian products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a big topic but I will keep it as short as I can. The Uruguay Round of GATT talks is regrettably in a state of considerable confusion just one week before its scheduled conclusion in Brussels next week. There are a great many issues, covering major subjects in the Round, where positions of the major participants appear to be too far apart now to enable a comprehensive conclusion to the negotiations by the end of next week.

ANSWER.PARA: The most significant area of those for Australia and, indeed, for the Round as a whole, where there appears at the moment to be no basis for negotiation is, regrettably, in agriculture. The Cairns Group and the United States have proposed, of course, that support and protection in agriculture be substantially reduced over the next decade. The European Community's response to its commitment substantially to reduce agricultural support and protection has been to offer only minimal reductions in internal support, leaving border protection and export subsidies without any firm commitments to reform. It is for that reason that the EC offer is considered by this Government, by other Cairns Group countries and by the United States to be totally deficient in critical respects.

Regrettably, despite pressure at the highest levels from our own Government and other governments seeking reform in agriculture, the EC has indicated that it has absolutely minimal flexibility in negotiations. Obviously, we hope that the EC will be able to bring to the Brussels meeting next week a greater flexibility and a greater sense of commitment to reform. A failed agricultural negotiation will have significant detrimental effects on the Round as a whole and therefore on the future health of the multilateral trading system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several days ago, Senator Boswell asked me a question concerning the labelling of country of origin on food products imported into Australia. He referred in particular to the labelling of imported orange juice products. I strongly believe that Australian consumers have the right to know the country of origin of the foodstuffs they purchase. I hope that people certainly have a very good look at the label which must be displayed on all packaged food.

ANSWER.PARA: The minimum requirement is that the country of origin label be 1.5 millimetres high. I only wish that those distributing Australian food products would adopt even larger labelling denoting Australian origin to encourage Australians to buy our farm produce. Some do; some do not; more should. I believe that distributors and retailers should be advocating to their suppliers that where a food product is Australian, it should be proudly labelled that way in bold print.

Whether the minimum should be greater than 1.5 millimetres, which was the question put to me, is a matter of dispute. I will give some comparisons: health warnings on tobacco products are 4 millimetres high; the tar and nicotine content is displayed 1.5 millimetres high; and health warnings on food products are 3 millimetres high. In relation to whether 1.5 millimetres is a suitable minimum, I have recently asked for two things to be done. I have asked the Australian Food Standards Committee to look at the matter and I have asked the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to liaise with Professor Tony Worsley of the National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health, who is working on the benefits to consumers of food labelling information.

As to orange juice, which is the second part of Senator Boswell's question, I am very concerned that orange juice concentrate is being imported into Australia and being converted into orange juice by either the addition of water or simple blending with local single strength juice and the resultant product is being labelled as `Made in Australia' or `Product of Australia'. Recently, a South Australian survey showed some products contained only 25 per cent of local orange juice but were being marketed and labelled as `Product of Australia'. I believed this matter was of such concern that I asked the Australian Food Standards Committee, which met in Perth yesterday, to fast track a recommendation to all Australian Ministers to require that orange juice products containing imported ingredients are labelled as such. Yesterday, the Committee recommended that the label `Made in Australia from Imported Ingredients' be attached to such orange juice. I hope Ministers act on that immediately.

I strongly support the proposition that consumers are entitled to know the truth about the origin of the food and beverages they buy. I have asked the Trade Practices Commission to examine whether some current labelling might mislead or deceive consumers as to the country of origin. Consumers should be able to make an informed choice, and I hope that that choice favours Australian products and therefore farmers and orchardists who are working so hard in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of Senator Button's response and the minute paper which was incorporated into Hansard from the Australian Taxation Office, we have an unparalleled situation whereby the Commissioner of Taxation, Trevor Boucher, has been made the sacrificial lamb for the political indiscretions of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is responsible for the Australian Taxation Office. Unfortunately, we now have one indiscretion compounded upon another with that unfortunate minute being introduced into the Parliament to defend the indefensible. That process has brought the Taxation Office's administration into disrepute.

SPEECH.PARA: In our Westminster system, the role of a member of the Executive Council, which is indeed a senior position, demands maturity and a respect for the law and an ability to cope with the cut and thrust of parliamentary performance, on the one hand, and an even-handedness in the execution of administrative functions in looking after, in this case, the Australian Taxation Office, on the other hand. However, neither the Commissioner nor the Parliamentary Secretary claims support from the minutes of the National Taxation Liaison Group-and that was not surprising because of the brevity in this area. The many parties had to rely on memory and, to be kind to each of the participants, there were certainly some variations which perhaps could be on the agenda at the next meeting of the National Taxation Liaison Group.

Senator McMullan still has to reply to an incomplete presentation. For example, I ask: Why did he not at the time quote to the Senate the issues which were raised in clause 7 of Mr Boucher's memorandum, in which Mr Boucher said that it seemed that the solution to the substantiation matter could in practice be found by giving some sort of discretionary power to the Commissioner? This was a blatant omission by the Parliamentary Secretary and would have changed the thrust of the whole debate-and the Parliamentary Secretary knew that.

On the matter of discretions, the one that I provided was a relieving provision, and I remind the Senate that these will always be in taxation law and are not as repressive as the others which we are finding incorporated and included in the foreign income legislation which is yet to come before this Parliament. They are the objectionable provisions; the relieving ones are acceptable. Unfortunately, the Parliamentary Secretary chose not to provide that segregation. He should have known a lot better. However, what was objectionable was the use by the Parliamentary Secretary of a tax liaison meeting to support the thrust of a Government response to a member of the Opposition.

Most people believe that the role of the National Taxation Liaison Group is to provide independent advice and views to the Australian Taxation Office in relation to taxation law and practice, and not to act as an instrument of government against any opposition.

I find perhaps even more incredible the humiliating position in which the Parliamentary Secretary has now placed the Commissioner of Taxation. I refer to the tabling of that minute from Trevor Boucher, the Commissioner of Taxation, in its present form. Some people have described this document as quite astounding; others have said it is a remarkable document. It is quite a self-incriminating piece of paper. I quote from paragraph 9 of the document which was incorporated in the Hansard:
It was also agreed that because of the nature of the issue, the outcome should be conveyed internally to taxation officers by me, and internally to practitioners and their representatives.

This means that the Australian Taxation Office is now applying an illegal de facto discrimination whereby there will be an effective picking of winners and losers and no guarantee of equal treatment. It is a shonky arrangement, and it is quite clear that this outcome is not a solution to the problems facing taxpayers, particularly honest taxpayers such as the Evangelist, who are the losers in this type of situation.

It is now up to the Government to do the right thing and to speedily amend the law, because what is at risk is the integrity of the tax law, and this-as a result of this action and because of these indiscretions, one upon another-is now very much at stake. I therefore call upon the Minister to dispel the rumour that is widely circulating that the Evangelist case was not an unfortunate one but was carefully selected to dramatise the fact that the Taxation Office was determined to enforce the full rigours of the law, an enforcement that made the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) quite livid.

To dispel this assertion, I now call upon the Minister to ensure that the Evangelist case be re-examined; to ensure that the tax is not administered in a discriminatory fashion but is even-handed. It is now a matter of urgency for the Government to bring in legislation to clear the practice of the Taxation Office and the Government's administration of taxation law in Australia. Again, the vehicle could be an internal ombudsman reporting regularly to a Senate committee or the establishment of a board of internal review.

We cannot afford to have this no interest approach. Butterworths Pty Ltd, in the weekly circular to its members, was appalled about the Government's attitude to this particular issue. The Opposition is providing the vehicle but the Government is not prepared to take it up. Perhaps the establishment of a board of internal review would also be another part solution, and perhaps this is not far from the mind of Senator McMullan, seeing that he has seen fit to table this internal minute publicly.

I remind the Senate that in the past the Government has not been loath to incorporate some of the best ideas from certain private member's Bills in Government legislation. But, in this circumstance, what is so disappointing is the Government's fundamental opposition to the concepts and to the Bill. My simple Bill, the Income Tax Assessment (Substantiation Requirements) Amendment Act 1990, introduced a degree of latitude in allowing deductions under section 51, where the taxpayer had satisfied section 190(b), the onus of proof provisions, but was unable to obtain a deduction because of the tightness or the rigours of the substantiation provision.

I remind the Senate that the Bill sought to provide a legal basis for the exercise of an appropriate discretion to apply the law with commonsense, and in doing so we would not be placing the Commissioner above the Parliament. In the present situation, with this administrative discretion, there is effectively no appeal. That is an atrocious system of administration of law. We must have a proper appeal mechanism. The Government is going about its business and is encouraging the Taxation Office to apply administrative commonsense from which there is no appeal to a senior authority such as the AAT or a court. That is quite reprehensible in a democracy. Minister Evans, as a lawyer, surely could not support that sort of proposal.

It will be around that legislative discretion that the Commissioner, in my case, could then have drafted adequate income tax rulings. I ask that the matter be reviewed as a matter of urgency to respect the integrity of the administration and the application of tax law in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There is the concern of the Commissioner and the Taxation Liaison Group that led to its expressing the view to the Commissioner that it did not believe that the legislation should be changed, which I conveyed to the chamber and which I shared. However, the nature of the discretion which he sought to put into the legislation caused the Government concern because it was too wide and it would have served to undermine the strictness of the substantiation rules and would therefore have opened up the potential for the very abuses which the strict substantiation rules were brought in to overcome.

That does not mean that unreviewable discretions are in any way preferable to reviewable ones, and I would not in the slightest contend that, nor would, I am sure, any of those officers to whom I am referring. I intend to continue to try to find a formula which will achieve that part of the objectives which Senator Watson and I, and I know the Australian Democrats, share. The tabling of the fifty-seventh report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission provides me with an ideal opportunity to express a number of concerns about the manner in which the payment of Grants Commission funds is impacting upon my State of Tasmania. Before I do, however, I would like to make special mention of the 17 years of dedicated service which Professor R.L. Mathews AO CBE gave to the Commission. Professor Mathews resigned as a member of the Commission on 31 January 1990. I believe it is appropriate that the Senate acknowledges his long and selfless period of service.

The Commonwealth Grants Commission is a statutory authority operating under the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973. The primary function of the Commission is to recommend to the Government the share of general revenue assistance made available by the Commonwealth which is finally adopted at the Premiers Conference. On page 12 of the report we see reference to a report prepared by the Commission into issues affecting fiscal equalisation into the 1990s. The Commission has been required to make a number of recommendations on matters which it believes to be relevant to a review of the application of the fiscal equalisation arrangements.

I have long held the view that serious mitigating factors affect the ability of local government authorities to raise revenue and pass on any increases in costs when unweighted population figures are used as a basis for determining shares of the total funds available for financial assistance grants, and that the use of such figures should be totally discontinued. Quite clearly, as the economy continues to deteriorate, services to the Tasmanian local government community will become increasingly dependent upon the level of untied financial assistance grants.

In this context, it is my view that funds must be distributed between the States and Territories in a manner which reflects the application of fiscal equalisation principles. In a practical sense, fiscal equalisation means that after grants have been made to the local government sector for each State when considered as a whole, local government units in each State are able to provide services comparable to those provided in other States if they make a comparable effort to raise taxes and charges.

Therefore, fiscal equalisation, when applied to grant allocation, means that those States and Territories that may suffer disadvantage due to factors such as isolation or a scattered population which is expensive to service are compensated for those special disabilities. It is reasonably easy to see that where the opposite applies and funds are limited to an arbitrary formula, for example, population or the number of properties, on the one hand it will be these States and Territories which are unintentionally assisted, and on the other hand, those with contrary figures which are penalised unintentionally.

There are several factors which affect the capacity of Tasmanian local government authorities to raise revenue. One glaring example is the low value of real estate properties when compared with mainland States. In Tasmania, for example, $150,000 will purchase a very nice home. In many mainland areas, such an amount will purchase little more than a shack. Rating base is another area in which Tasmanian councils struggle to match their mainland counterparts. Several mainland capital city areas contain a higher population than that of Tasmania as a whole. Major regional centres and dense commercial and industrial developments do not occur in Tasmania.

These very brief features demonstrate the extra effort required to generate a matching amount of rating income. Further to this can be added the fact that, when compared with the mainland, wages and salaries are lower for comparable positions in Tasmania. The necessary result of a lower household income means the imposition of a maximum on the amount of rates that can realistically be levied.

It is also important to remember that, whilst there is a limit to how much Tasmanian councils can raise by way of revenue, there are also costs which must be borne which are far and above those costs facing councils on the mainland. I refer, of course, to freight imposts across Bass Strait and other matters, such as petrol costs-we have increased petrol taxes because of freight-and our limited rail system. Most of our internal freight goes by road, with higher fuel costs reflected in higher cartage costs. The point remains that fiscal equalisation remains the only method of equitable grants distribution.

The speech read as follows-
This Bill proposes several amendments to Acts dealing with Defence matters. The more important changes:
a. amend Defence Force retirement and death benefits legislation to index children's pensions, and to enable surviving spouses to commute part of their pension; and
b. exempt Commonwealth-owned Defence companies from capital gains tax on assets acquired by the Commonwealth before the imposition of that tax.
Other amendments remove obsolete provisions requiring the Governor-General's authorisation for certain Defence activities, and make technical drafting amendments.
I will now deal with the more important amendments. The other changes are explained in the Explanatory Memorandum.
RETIREMENT AND DEATH BENEFITS LEGISLATION

These amendments alter the arrangements for the payment of benefits under existing Defence Force superannuation and death benefits provisions to the spouses, children and orphans of deceased members of the Defence Force.

The Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Review Committee recommended that spouses be provided with the option to commute a portion of their pension entitlement (that is, the equivalent of two years of their former spouse's salary for pension purposes at the time of death) to a lump sum. It also recommended that the fixed rate elements of children's and orphans' benefits ($312 and $5000 respectively) be indexed to movements in the consumer price index.
The Government accepted these recommendations, and has taken the opportunity to include the necessary amendments in this Bill.

Commutation for spouses will generally be available from the date of commencement of the legislation. However, there is special provision to ensure that in the unfortunate event of any casualties in the Persian Gulf deployment prior to the commencement of the amendment, a surviving spouse will also be eligible for commutation.
Indexation of the fixed rate elements of children's and orphans' benefits will commence from the first pension pay day in July 1990.

I emphasise that all of these changes are beneficial and thus in accord with the ``Ironclad Guarantee'' given by the Government at the time the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Review was announced that the benefits for which serving Defence Force personnel were currently contributing would continue to be available to them when they left the Defence Force.
CAPITAL GAINS TAX RELIEF FOR DEFENCE COMPANIES

The Senate will be aware that the Government has taken a number of initiatives to improve efficiency within the Defence portfolio. A key step in achieving greater efficiency has been the commercialisation and corporatisation of Defence production activities, with the establishment of the Commonwealth-owned companies Aerospace Technologies of Australia and Australian Defence Industries.

These companies are in the process of adapting to direct competition from other Australian and foreign companies, and are expected to operate in the open market with only commercial restrictions and controls on their mode of operation. In this context, it is important that the companies are not placed at a disadvantage in comparison with their competitors. A case in point is taxation.

The current rules dealing with the application of capital gains tax provide an exemption for assets acquired before imposition of that tax, on 20 September 1985, and also provide roll-over relief from the tax where such assets have been transferred to subsidiaries of companies but the underlying ownership of the assets has not changed.

Although the underlying ownership of their assets has not changed, this roll-over relief is not at present available to the Defence companies because the Commonwealth is not a taxpayer. Provision is therefore necessary to give these companies the same roll-over relief from capital gains tax as that obtained by subsidiary companies within corporate groups when assets are transferred within the group.

The proposed relief is in respect of assets that were acquired by the Commonwealth before 20 September 1985 and transferred to the companies in connection with their establishment. An associated amendment will ensure that the value of those assets in the calculation of depreciation for taxation purposes is the depreciated value that would have applied had the Commonwealth been a taxpayer claiming normal depreciation.
FINANCIAL IMPACT
Indexing the children's (including orphans') pensions for the financial year from 1 July 1990 will cost approximately $92,000. The future cost will depend on the rate of inflation.
Surviving spouses' right to commute pension could cost up to $1.2 million in the first full year. This will be offset by reduced pension in future years.

The capital gains tax concession will reduce revenue by $2.2 million this financial year. Future impact would depend on capital sales. This will be offset to some extent by increased revenue stemming from the associated depreciation adjustment.
The other provisions in the Bill are not expected to have any significant financial impact.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

There was the new technology which people had to adapt to. Multiskilling also was enhanced during that period.

As I mentioned earlier, that is where it started in the mid-1970s.

As a consequence of that, entitlements which accrue to SES officers will now accrue to ministerial staff and all leaders' staff members. As part of that linking, the ministerial staff allowance, which applies to some senior officers in offices in this place, will no longer apply when performance pay applies. At the same time as that, in the linkage, motor cars are made available to appropriate senior staffers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to a reservation that I put into the Department of Employment, Education and Training in respect of a Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) directive to potential employees of non-union organisations. The whole basis of voluntary employment agreements-and this is what causes the disturbance within the power structure of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)-is that an agreement is reached between an employer and his employees without any outside involvement of either employer organisations or the structured trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: On 22 January 1990, a fax was sent to the Commonwealth Employment Service offices throughout Queensland, I believe, which stated that:

Telephone advice has just been received from central office that the CES should not accept vacancies involving voluntary employment agreements (VEA), nor should job seekers be referred to any such vacancies.
A formal minute confirming this information will be forwarded to you as soon as confirmation in writing is received from central office (expected in the next day or so.)

It is signed by Mr DeYoung. A couple of days later, a letter was sent to all employment office managers and zone managers for information. It referred to the Job Bank Message, as it is called, of 22 January which confirmed that. It was again signed by Mr DeYoung `for the Manager, Network Coordination Unit'.

In Estimates I asked these questions-and I will summarise them: first, was a directive issued to State CES officers? Secondly, what would be the legislative basis for that directive? Thirdly, would it be considered discriminatory, bearing in mind that a minority of employers in the private sector in fact have union labour? Fourthly, would it not reduce the job opportunities for young people who wish to get a job within those organisations?

I subsequently received a response-well after the closing date of the Estimates report. It is fascinating that the response was that the directive was issued by the Department at the request of the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin). So here we have the Minister coming in, presumably at the request of the ACTU-the club-and saying, `For goodness sake, do not let us, do not let the CES operation, offer jobs to people if they have a voluntary employment agreement'. The instance to which I refer is a legitimate one from an industrial relations point of view. It received the blessing of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

When I asked what the legislative basis was, the answer was that, the directive having been issued by the Minister, under administrative arrangements orders Ministers are given responsibility for the administration of their portfolios. I have to say that, in the time I have been here, I have yet to see such a lame excuse for doing something that can be described only as petty in the extreme.

That did not worry Mini Movers one iota. An advertisement in a newspaper could get the company as many people as it wanted-particularly these days with the rise in unemployment which is attributable to the Government's policies. I raise that matter with the Minister because, frankly, I think that what the then Minister for Employment and Education Services did is something that needs to be brought to the attention of the Australian public. The agreement was not secretive; it was an amendment to an award that had been registered, and yet that particular little company was being discriminated against. The same rule applies to Power Brewing Co. Ltd and it will be interesting to see what happens now. In a subsequent answer it was indicated that, as the legislation has now been abolished in Queensland by the State Government, this was no longer a problem. QUESTION ON NOTICE
ATSIC AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION
Senator Teague asked in regard to an auditors' report of the Barwon Aboriginal Community Ltd dated 15 February 1989:
1. Would either of these reservations be of concern to ATSIC if they received such an audit?
2. Would ATSIC think it reasonable and responsible to question why a full systems review had not taken place, if presented such a report?
3. Is ATSIC aware whether or not it is in fact illegal not to see the register of directors, managers and secretaries when awaiting a registered company?
4. Does ATSIC find it at all unusual that a community in Walgett uses for their audit, an accountant in Gympie?
5. If ATSIC was presented with such an audit, could ATSIC have reasonable surety that monies were not being misappropriated?
6. Would ATSIC think it strange that on receipt of such a report, funds should continue to be advanced?

7. If such audits had in fact been provided over successive years, would it not be negligent to continue funding without an attempt to ensure that internal control was such that monies were not properly spent.
Response
Question 1

Yes, in regard to a systems review and evaluation of internal control, if there were indications from other sources or from the auditor's financial statement that there were possible systems weaknesses or mismanagement occurring. It is preferable, of course, to have both matters fully addressed in every report but, given the locality, the availability of auditors and the cost, this can not always occur.

With regard to the sighting of the register of Directors etc. this would not be considered a major issue as it is a requirement of the Companies Act not ATSIC grant rules. ATSIC is concerned to ensure that the organisation is firstly incorporated and that it will continue to be so while receiving ATSIC funding and as such ATSIC encourages organisations to comply with all of their incorporation requirements.
Question 2

Yes, but ATSIC does not believe that a full systems review is required each financial year unless there is evidence of possible mismanagement. Costs of a full systems review can be a prohibitive factor.
Question 3

Under the Companies (NSW) Code 1981, there are penalties for companies not maintaining their Register of Directors. ATSIC is aware that it is an essential step of most company audits to inspect the Register of Members and Directors. However, ATSIC does not believe that it is illegal for auditor's not to sight this Register. It appears from the auditor's report that he, in fact, did attempt to sight the Register but it was not available. ATSIC understands that the Register now exists.
Question 4
No, Barwon continued to use their existing auditor after he had moved to Gympie. The north west of NSW has always been poorly serviced by auditors. Barwon has since changed auditors.
Question 5

ATSIC considers that it would have reasonable surety that monies are not being misappropriated given that project officers maintain constant contact with organisations and that the organisations are also required to provide other financial and physical reports. If an auditor continued not to provide a detailed report or there were reasons to suspect misappropriation, then an auditor's report including a full systems review and internal control evaluation would be requested prior to further funds being released.
Question 6
No, given the above reasons.
Question 7

Yes, it would be negligent if no action was taken, especially if mismanagement was suspected. ATSIC focuses considerable resources on improving client management and accounting systems. In Barwon's case, ATSIC has provided assistance to computerise its accounting system and train staff. Currently, ATSIC is funding two professional accounting advisers to assist the organisation.
