They are making a profit out of perhaps naive people, but certainly well-intentioned people, and are not really being asked to perform.

I have no difficulties with the market system provided that the market is a fair one. I am just concerned that the system as it runs at the moment does not seem to be doing the right thing by the intending migrant. As I said, it is causing a certain degree of anxiety amongst the ethnic community.

My other concern is that it would appear that the Department is relying very much on those accredited migration consultants not just to prepare the application but to assist migrants after they come to this country. It may be that I am wrong. If it is the case that the Department is relying on accredited migration consultants to assist migrants after they have come to the country, it appears to me, from the anecdotal evidence available to me, that that function is not being performed, because in many cases the accredited migration consultants reside outside this country and do not have an affiliate within this country.

There are some very sound and fine migration consultants who are affiliated with organisations or persons within this country who, I believe, do a good job, but there are many more who are not affiliated and who appear to be only filling out the forms and not doing anything else. If there is an area where we can improve the business migration system it would perhaps be there, because from the anecdotal evidence available to me the scheme is breaking down at that point. These people come here with good intentions but, for reasons of cultural difficulty, do not seem to be able to carry them through. Maybe that is an area that the Department needs to look at to improve the service that it makes available and the efficiency and effectiveness of the business migration system.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do have a system of accredited migration agents-and they are accredited within Australia. Some of those companies, of course, have international networks. The Department is keen to ensure that there is quality control of the scheme, and to that extent licences have been and will be withdrawn. If Senator O'Chee has any other specific complaints, I am sure the Department is quite keen to entertain them and act on them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —If further comments are made to me in that area, I will follow them up. I am very grateful for that because, as I said, it is an area that is causing some anxiety.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps it would be appropriate to move on to the special humanitarian program and the problems currently being faced in the assessment of various types of refugee applications. One of the concerns that I have is that it does not appear that there will be sufficient resources available to process many of the applications.

For example, I understand that Chinese student applications in various categories are taking 12 months for screening. Some Chinese students who have made applications to stay in this country, who are awaiting work permits and have been asked to fill out the necessary forms, are being told that they will not be able to get the work permits until they have been interviewed under the Determination of Refugee Status Committee (DORS) procedures. When they ask when they will be interviewed by DORS, the answer is, `Probably in about 12 months time, and no special circumstances are being taken into consideration'. That is causing a great deal of hardship, resulting in some of those intending applicants working illegally and, thus, breaking the system down.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that this is an area which has been under Government consideration for some time. The objective of the Government is to enable processing of these sorts of applications within a nine-month period. To that effect, Cabinet has recently allocated extra resources to the Department for this particular function. I know Senator O'Chee will be pleased to hear that over the last fiscal year there has been a capacity for a fourfold increase in resources in this particular area. The Government also recognises that there will be a need for ongoing resources in this area, so it will not be a one-off this financial year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take that as a sufficient answer to my question; obviously when we come back and look at the Estimates in six months or 12 months time we will be better able to assess how well that has worked. I am very pleased that has been done because it has tended to make the whole system unworkable.

SPEECH.PARA: I would prefer, therefore, to move on to the discussion of English language intensive courses for overseas students (ELICOS) visas, which was the last area where I made reservations. When the matter was examined on 20 September, I was concerned that there did not seem to be any sufficient check on the origin of the money that would be used to finance a student's expenses in this country. Mr Bugden from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs agreed that the cost of a student staying in Australia for six months was approximately $4,000 in course fees, with living expenses of about $2,000.

The concern I had at that time, and the concern I still have, is that in many cases the money is not coming from outside this country but, rather, is coming from within this country, that is, the money is borrowed from an individual or a company in Australia and is being repaid through the student working in this country. The whole purpose of the ELICOS scheme was to earn export dollars for Australia. Therefore, I would like to extend to the Minister the opportunity to comment on that in a general sense so that, if I am incorrect in that assumption or if I am incorrect in saying that currently nothing is being done to check where the money comes from, he can correct that matter now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the first point to make here is that a number of mechanisms can be utilised to ensure that those applying to come in under the scheme are bona fide. There has been a substantial tightening of checks over this year. For instance, at the moment nine out of 10 applying from the People's Republic of China are not getting through the system because they are not assessed as being bona fide. Having said that the Government has recognised and put in place tightened checks across the board in assessing whether someone is a bona fide student or not, I should also say that we do make checks as far as possible in respect of the money trail, but it is, I think it is fair to say, not possible, I am advised, to enhance those checks that apply at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator O'Chee's concern is to ensure that a bona fide student is the only one who comes here. The whole range of enhanced checks that are in place this year has ensured that that has applied, as far as possible, to date. I do, however, ask Senator O'Chee to recognise that to follow the money trail is sometimes just not possible. It is not possible to do more than we are doing at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage it might be appropriate to refer to questions and answers that were given on 20 September, when I questioned Mr Bugden about this. On page D143 I am reported to have said:

SPEECH.PARA: When you talk about access to funds, does that also mean loans available to the applicants at the time at which they apply?
Mr Bugden answered:
If they have got that money. The source of the funds does not matter terribly much to us, providing they have the funds.
I then asked:
So quite possibly people could justify their ability to pay upon the basis that a loan would be made available to them in Australia?
Then Mr Gibbons answered:

It is possible. I emphasise the point made by Mr Bugden: an assessment is made of a person's capacity to earn while in Australia. Part of the rationale behind the scheme involves time for the students to work to earn income, to offset the costs of their stay and their education in Australia.

He then recommends further questioning of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. My concern is that quite clearly the Department is aware that many students are financing the cost of their education and their stay in this country solely from work within Australia rather than from money outside, and that would appear to be a clear admission by at least the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs that the system has broken down.

TALK.START.PARA: —I anticipate that it would satisfy Senator O'Chee's concerns if I were to say that evidence of a person's capacity to repay a loan or to pay for his or her stay in Australia is taken into account when an assessment is made of whether a person is a bona fide student or not. That, coupled with the fact that checks have been tightened and that, as a result of those tightened checks, there has been a substantial reduction in the number of people coming in, I think effectively meets the two concerns. The point to be made about the question that Senator O'Chee asked is that we really cannot stop people from coming in just because they have borrowed money to come in. However, we need to ensure that they have the capacity to pay off a loan once they are here. That is part of the test applied to ensure that a person applying is a bona fide intending student.

—I am pleased to see that the tests have been tightened up. But that still does not answer my principal concern that we are not really earning export dollars. The whole purpose of this scheme was to earn millions of dollars for Australia every year from the money that would come into the country. We now find that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is admitting that the money does not come into the country. The money exists in this country; it is borrowed outside this country and is repaid from earnings in this country, so it is not really earning anything more for this country. All that is being achieved is that jobs are being taken from Australians. That is not a racist comment. In fact, it is a comment made to me in some respects by the Chinese community. It appears that many nationals of the People's Republic of China, who have very limited access to funds in their home country, are coming to Australia under the English language intensive courses for overseas students scheme, working for six months and repaying, solely from their endeavours within Australia, the money that they have borrowed. The people they are taking jobs from are Australian born Chinese or Chinese who have migrated to this country and become Australian citizens. The concern and consternation of the Chinese community over this matter is very great. I extend another opportunity to the Minister to say whether Mr Gibbons's and Mr Bugden's comments are correct-that the Department does not really care where the money comes from.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to say that what is of importance is the assessment of whether a student is a genuine, bona fide student or not. To that extent, a whole range of questions is asked. I will give to Senator O'Chee later on a pamphlet produced by the Department for use by applicants under the English language intensive courses for overseas students scheme. Within that, it is fair to say that those who have borrowed to come to Australia and to study are not denied entry because of the fact that they have had to borrow rather than being able to bring money with them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator O'Chee raised a concern about the People's Republic of China (PRC). It is a concern that has been put to me also by my friends in the community. I think there was wider concern in the community some time ago, but I ask Senator O'Chee to take into account the fact that, with the enhanced checking in this area to which I referred earlier, nine out of 10 intending students from PRC are now denied entry because they are not assessed as being bona fide students.

There is more than one aim or objective for this program. The export of education services and getting money from overseas students is one objective, but not the only one. The enhanced checking has produced results already and I think Senator O'Chee would accept that that has ensured that the students that he is concerned about-the non-bona fide ones-do not come in.

I ask Senator O'Chee to consider that, for instance, Australian students going to study overseas are not denied access to that study because they borrow to go and study. There has to be some fairness in this. But at the same time let us take as the important consideration that we will allow in genuine students and, to that extent, the tightening of the criteria and the enforcement of them has enhanced the program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again it does not seem appropriate at this point for me to continue asking questions. I will therefore make a comment to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), and again he is free to respond to it if he wishes. I understand the Minister's point about bona fide students; I think that is a very important point.

SPEECH.PARA: From my understanding, one of the selling points of the English language intensive courses for overseas students (ELICOS) scheme is that it would earn export dollars for Australia. It now appears that it is not earning as many export dollars as was originally intended. Instead, we are now finding other points being thrown up as principal reasons for the scheme. When Mr Dawkins, I believe, talked about the scheme when it was first mooted, it was one of the ways of making Australia an exporter of education and, hence, of increasing the wealth of the nation. We now find that what the Minister has said is a back down of the Government's position because the earning of export dollars is not the sole principal criteria-it now seems to be giving education to people. I do not find that terribly satisfactory.

The Minister said that when Australian students go overseas they have an opportunity to borrow money. Yes, that is true. I did my university degree overseas, but the point I make is that I was not allowed to work in the United Kingdom for all the time I was there. It was a condition of the visa that I was not allowed to work. In fact, it was also a condition of the visa that the money to pay for my education had to originate from outside the United Kingdom.

I understand all the arguments: we have an obligation to South East Asia and to other developing countries; that this does something towards improving international relations and improving our friendships overseas, and hence the standing of Australia in 10 or 20 years time. I understand all those things, but what I do not understand is why the Government should hide behind the fiction that the ELICOS scheme is successfully earning dollars for Australia when quite clearly that has been misplaced and there are now other justifications for the scheme. If there are other justifications for the scheme, I believe that it is incumbent upon the Government to come clean with those justifications, say exactly what it is attempting to achieve with the ELICOS scheme and then let us get on with the job. What I do not like is the use of fiction to justify what is being done.

Again I say that there is still real concern in the community about the students who are working. I went into a Chinese restaurant in Brisbane for lunch. I subsequently had meetings afterwards, had dinner, worked a little bit later and then came back for late evening coffee in a hotel. The period of time that elapsed had been about 10 hours. I was very surprised to find the same waitress serving me in the hotel as had served me lunch in the restaurant. She explained very simply that she works something like 15 hours on a Sunday, works also on other days and works well in excess of the 20 hours.

There are substantial flaws and loopholes in the scheme and it is not working at the moment. I have said in the past and repeat that unless this scheme can be tightened up, run properly and unless we can be assured that we are actually earning export dollars for Australia, the scheme ought to go because at the moment it is the soft underbelly of immigration into this country. It is being used for all sorts of other rorts. I have no problems with bona fide students who are coming in and bringing dollars into this country in the same way that I was asked to take dollars over to the United Kingdom. But what I do find objectionable is that so many other jobs are being lost and so many people are being disadvantaged.

I just make one point while we are talking about this because the biggest overstayers, from the latest figures that I have seen, are not in fact the People's Republic of China nationals at all. They do overstay in excess of the average for student visas, but they are not the biggest overstayers. All I am saying is that the whole system needs to be tightened up. If we cannot tighten it up and get clear in our own heads why we are running the scheme, then we have to question the existence of the scheme itself.

Therefore, I repeat my previous comments. It is time that we got the purpose of the scheme clear and it is time that we started to really crack down on the people who are using the scheme and disadvantaging Australians. If we cannot do both of those things it is time we threw the scheme out the door, because it is just not working.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise some matters in respect of program 1.2, relating to workplace reform. As I put in my reservation, I have a number of additional questions and examinations I would like to ask in respect of that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I raise the issue of the expenditure involved in the establishment of the various reform centres. In examining this, I am curious to learn why there are enormous differences between the establishment costs of the various centres. If one looks at the situation in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, one finds they required only $241,000 in the initial grant. However, when one looks at other centres, particularly the Hunter centre, one finds that the establishment cost of that centre had blown out to $785,512. That is an extraordinary amount of money compared to the expenditure incurred for the establishment of the other centres. What did that expenditure relate to? Was it capital expenditure, or did it relate to structure and so on?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The $241,000 referred to for the other centres named by Senator Crane relates to the capital costs of setting up those centres and the fact that it took up to five months in each case to get those centres established, resourced and up and running.

SPEECH.PARA: The $785,000 for the Hunter centre, to which the honourable senator referred, includes both the capital and the recurrent costs. The Hunter centre is regarded by both the employer organisations that access it and the unions covered by it as the most efficient centre in Australia. The establishment time for that centre was short and truncated; it took six weeks to get it running. However, there was solid demand within the Hunter region for its services that had to be met in a very short time.

While that figure is both capital and recurrent, the other explanation about the size of the amount relates to the shortness of time in which it had to be established. That required a consideration about whether we met the earlier deadline to pick up the client base that stood there and could be picked up or we took a more leisurely stroll down the course and risked losing some of the client base that existed. That is the sort of decision one makes when one is in a position of promoting this type of commercial undertaking. They are the reasons for the extra amount.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that explanation. In summary, we are not comparing apples with apples; we are comparing apples with oranges. That was not clear in the report. I understand it was intended that these centres should be self-financing within approximately three years. Can the Minister advise the Senate what the total cost of all these centres is likely to be by June 1993? In addition, does the Minister have any information on fees received to date for the services provided? Having regard to the amount now received and the likely costs up to June 1993, will these centres have become profitable when the deadline arrives?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I may be in receipt in a moment of some advice about the total costs by June 1993; someone is scribbling feverishly away in the corner. It is the Government's intention that these centres be self-financing and independent business entities operating on a tripartite basis to help speed the process of workplace change.

SPEECH.PARA: The position of the Government is that we would cease any financial support by then. If they could not survive in the marketplace, they would fold. If they could survive in the marketplace and be commercial propositions, they would be outside the Government's immediate control but working nonetheless within the articles of association and the registered objectives of the organisations. They would still be rendering that service as self-supporting organisations.

The workplace resource centre based in the Hunter, and to a slightly lesser extent the Sydney centre, are coming close now to being self-financing and look like coming in well under the three-year period. Although the centre in Perth was only opened-by me, actually-earlier this year, it has succeeded magnificently in attracting clients from a whole spectrum of industry. I would expect it to be another centre which would become self-financing, certainly within the three-year period, and maybe a lot quicker than might otherwise be the case.

I am able to confirm that the New South Wales and Hunter centres are essentially self-financing now. Western Australia, Victoria and South Australia are coming close to that point. The fees already received by them-this is their income-amount to close to $1m. Total outlays by 1993, for the seven centres around Australia, would probably be $10m, or a figure of that order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the Minister's answer that funding would cease by 1993. My next question relates to the establishment costs and what occurs when the centres come into profitability. Will that profitability remain with those organisations or will it be returned to government? If it is to remain with the centres, will there be a system whereby the government investment is in fact recouped from those centres?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is a very good question. The present arrangement is that the centres would use their profitability to reinvest to improve the quality and extension of their services. Their articles of association, as I understand them, require that that cannot go into higher remuneration or any outrageous level of remuneration for the people employed there. It must go into the improvement of the quality and scope of the services. This program was under way when I assumed this portfolio. As part of my commitment to review all the elements of the portfolio, the question that Senator Crane has asked occurred to me.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not yet taken any initiative on the subject, but what emboldens me to consider it further is that a number of these centres have proved to be able to reach sustainability a lot quicker than anticipated. Whilst I have not yet addressed the matter, it is still open, as far as I am concerned, as to whether, in the face of that good performance, there will be a requirement for part of the moneys or all of the moneys to be repaid at some level or in some form. That is a matter that I have not finally resolved, but it is under active consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I urge very strongly, and it is my view, that the long term objective should be to recover those funds if the centres do come into profitability. Once again, I will summarise two or three questions to endeavour to save time. I note that New South Wales has two centres; none of the other States has two. This leads me to a concern relating to rural Australia. Of course, Senator Cook is well aware, as are other honourable senators, that there are some difficulties, particularly with small business, the farm sector and some mining enterprises in rural areas. I would like to find out what accessibility rural businesses have to this service and what services are provided.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give some examples: are there 008 toll free numbers whereby contact can be made? Do officers of the centres travel to the rural areas and service those particular areas? If so, how regularly, and what type of rural skills and knowledge do they have? Have any provisions been made in the scheme to provide specialist information to the farming community in association with businesses in these times?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, that is a very appropriate and responsible line of inquiry. The honourable senator is right that the Hunter centre is almost an example of spontaneous combustion, based on Newcastle in a heavily industrialised area. There has been for some time in that region a call for services of this nature. As I said in my answer to the first question, thus it was that there was a demand for its services before we could actually establish the centre properly. But it is the only regionally located centre in Australia. It does occur to me that places such as Geelong, the Illawarra based on Port Kembla, the Whyalla-Port Pirie-Port Augusta triangle-the Iron Triangle in South Australia-parts of the north coast of Queensland, some of the hinterland major provincial cities in that State as well and, in our own State, Western Australia, the Pilbara region stand out as possible candidates for centres of this nature to be established in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Their focus is mainly in areas of industry where it is possible to reap the benefits of award restructuring by reforming workplace practice. To that extent, it may not always be something that is appropriate for the farming community. But, in my view, that is not something to be dismissed or put aside. If the farming community has an interest in looking at how employed labour can reach greater levels of productivity, then these centres should be open to meet that demand from there.

We do not have provision now for 008 numbers, and the travel to provincial areas is done from time to time depending on which industry-in the Western Australian case, which mining activity-is calling upon a contractual relationship between it and the centre to render its service. I know that places such as Darwin, where there is not a centre at this stage, and some of the other places have pooled their resources to supply a service. With the centres coming into profitability, I expect that a travel to regional centres budget can be worked out for them and they can better service those areas.

The last element of Senator Crane's question asked what types of skills and what types of services they actually provide. As the honourable senator knows, it is a commercial service where both unions and employers wish that service to be introduced. It is to look at how, under the advances made by restructuring of awards, by reducing the number of classifications to one, and by introducing multiskilled workers in place of rigid demarcations of particular skills, one can achieve efficiencies in the workplace. The centres advise that, firstly, they conduct a skills audit to see what the levels of skills might be at a particular enterprise, on contract. Having achieved an audit in association with the management and usually with the unions in the enterprise, they work out how career paths and training programs can be introduced to broaden the skill base in that enterprise and to create a more flexible work force better able to absorb new technology, new processes, new methods of doing things and work out, appropriate to the needs and the market that that enterprise serves, how high levels of productivity per head of employed worker can be generated.

Where employed labour is working on farms, there is some scope for that, but the more obvious focus is in heavier industry or in larger scale industry at this stage. That is not in any sense to deny the right of small business either, because it does have an interest in receiving these services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, this evening has great historic significance for all those who belong to the Australian Labor Party (ALP) or support its objectives. On this day, 28 November, we commemorate the occasion when the New South Wales Trades and Labour Council resolved to support a motion of one Robert Joseph Harris. Some would say that the ALP for a century has been sustained only by divine intervention. Given the splits of 1917, 1931 and 1954-57, that view has great merit. But a century ago this evening the resolution that Robert Harris moved read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That with a view of securing better representation of labour in Parliament, and to effectively organise all that are favourable to the said, object, this Council deems it advisable to establish Labour Electoral Leagues in every centre where practicable throughout the colony, and the Parliamentary Committee be instructed to prepare a scheme for the organisation and government of same.
In short, that is the original resolution that had as its objective the formation of the Australian Labor Party.

Mr Deputy President, as you are aware, this occurred hard on the consequences of the great strikes of the 1880s and 1890s, the great strikes in the maritime and pastoral industries in particular. It occurred as a consequence of the failures of the infant trade union movement and, hence, the peak body of the trade unions of the day, the Trades and Labour Council of New South Wales, took the decision through the Harris proposition to form a political labour movement. Hence, this evening, we are able to commemorate the initial decision that gave birth to the Australian Labor Party. One hundred years later, Harris's words have been fulfilled in the electoral successes of the ALP. The Trades and Labour Council was visualising the formation of a uniquely and original political party, one which would pave the way for the development of a more egalitarian and prosperous Australian society. On 17 June 1881, just one year after the formation of the Labour Electoral Leagues in New South Wales, the fledgling Labor Party won 35 of the 141 contested seats for the New South Wales Legislative Assembly. These elections brought to end the long-standing tradition of two party politics in New South Wales-liberal versus conservative-a tradition which had impeded political growth and had served to stratify the society of the State. Despite its infancy, the Labor Party managed to demonstrate beyond doubt to critics and supporters alike that Labor was a force to be reckoned with for the future-the future of Australian as well as New South Wales politics.
Mr Deputy President, the formation of the new party did not pass unnoticed, as this quote from the Sydney Morning Herald somewhat nervously anticipated:

The leaders of Labor seem to have set themselves a large task. They are preparing for more systematic and more completely organised action in the political world, and by way of preparation they are showing forth in a political sense the whole duty of men.

The opposition to the political wing of the labour movement has been hard and it has been enduring. In its initial stages, the Labor Party was greeted, again by the Sydney Morning Herald, in sarcastic terms. I quote from the newspaper:

The creation of a Labor Party in Parliament, if it did nothing else, must have a salutary effect in turning the minds of the unsatisfied among the working-classes to the right direction for the removal of their grievances, whether real or imagined . . . and good cannot fail to come of it if the appearance of such a party in Parliament is the means of removing any sense of grievance under which the working classes may have considered themselves to be suffering . . .

Some might suggest that one can continue to read sentiments of that kind in the Sydney Morning Herald currently, but that is what it said in 1891. The Labour Electoral Leagues were founded on the need of working Australians for political representation. Working Australians required a political party which endeavoured to deliver for them, through legislation, that which was needed to combat the injustices of the society at the time.

The Labor Party started simply from the basic need for the protection of the rights of working men and women. It started from the concern amongst ordinary Australians for their own future and for the future of their children. The catalyst for the decision of the Trades and Labour Council to form the ALP was the maritime strike of 1890, as I mentioned earlier. The defeat of the massive industrial action undertaken by trade unions, not only in New South Wales but all over the country, saw the beginning of a new era in Australian politics.

After a long period of economic growth, the end of the 1880s signalled the beginning of hard economic times. This precipitated a major industrial and then political confrontation. The strike in the maritime industry arose from efforts by unionists to protect their wages and conditions at a time when wages were falling and the economy was in decline. So it was in the pastoral industry almost at the same time. I will say a little bit more about the pastoral strike in a moment, but the Melbourne Age reported at the time of the maritime strike:

The shipowners are chiefly blamable for pushing this quarrel to the point of a rupture. They admit, and could scarcely deny that the officers have a perfect right to form a union for the promotion of their own interests . . .

In the circumstances of the maritime strike, the shipowners were victorious and the defeated unionists were left only with the realisation of the necessity of political action. It was a defeat that would have profound effects and consequences.

The labour movement discovered that it needed the strength of a political force in Parliament to adequately represent the interests of working Australians, for the States had been deployed by the conservative political parties against the trade unions. The police and the courts had been used as deliberate weapons to defeat the trade unions industrially. Mr Deputy President, everyone in the labour movement is familiar with the words from Reedy River about the pastoral strike at the end of the 1880s:
The price of wool was falling in eighteen ninety one;
The men who owned the acres saw something must be done:
`We'll break the shearers' union and show we're masters still,
And they'll take the terms we give them or we'll find the men who will!'.

Of course, history proved otherwise. The newly formed ALP sought to achieve as priorities free education, an eight-hour working day, fair wages, safe conditions for workers and the establishment of invalid and age pensions. I think it is fair to say that the ALP continues to this day to exemplify the spirit and intentions of its forefathers and foremothers.

The relationship between the political wing and industrial wing of the ALP continues to be a feature of our strength; a feature built on cooperation. The ALP and the trade union movement are bodies still acknowledging their original role as representing the interests of ordinary Australians. Our continued relationship is a reflection of the dynamism of the labour movement in this country. The labour movement has broadened its base and it now reflects the interests of the vast majority of working Australians.

The prices and incomes accord is a fine example of the cooperation and effectiveness of the political and industrial wings of Labor working together. It is, in fact, the manifestation of the historic relationship between the ALP and the trade union movement. As the Labor Party approaches the centenary of our electoral success in June of 1891 in New South Wales, and in different months in other States, our Party as a national organisation is looking at the structure of the Labor Party itself. We have to focus on the constituency party structure; we have to focus on the role of the parliamentary Labor parties; and we have to focus on the powers of our conferences at State and national levels.

We also have to focus on the historic nexus between political and industrial labour. This nexus has served us well for nearly a century. It distinguishes the ALP from our fraternal parties abroad, amongst other social democratic and democratic socialist parties. The nexus is a sheet anchor both for reference and for support, but it is appropriate that we examine its applicability for the future.

Political Labor in this country has never been seen to be dominated by the trade union movement as perhaps British Labour governments of the 1960s and 1970s were so perceived. The apparent domination of the Wilson and Callaghan Labour governments by a handful of enormous trade unions has never occurred in this country, nor will it. So at a time of trade union amalgamations leading to larger industrial organisations, and a time of greater diversity in the Australian electorate and in Labor's constituency, it is appropriate that the political and industrial nexus be examined. Many people in the Labor Party, myself included, will need to be convinced that the nexus ought to be altered; but a rational and deliberate debate on this and other matters relevant to our organisation is essential.

The decision of the Trades and Labour Council of New South Wales to form a political Labor wing highlighted the need for the labour movement to reach beyond trade unionism to all sympathetic Australians. The ALP continues to pursue new objectives and, at the same time, seeks to maintain its relevance in a modern industrial society. I believe we have achieved that. It is a matter of history that the ALP has led the way in areas such as environmental protection and issues associated with anti-discrimination while maintaining its customary role in the areas of social security, health, education, producing a sound economic policy and, over the decades, producing an independent foreign policy and a strong defence policy for this country.

Just as today it is the contribution of individuals who give the labour movement its place of prominence in Australia, so it is a matter of record that the vision and dedication of the pioneers of the early labour movement enabled the ALP to become the potent political force that it is today, in 1990. The ALP has been responsible for many achievements in this country's history. Again, it is a matter of our history. I know that Senator Collins, as someone who is steeped in the labour tradition, will acknowledge that the Labor Party has brought this country through wars, through depression, through a period of post-colonialism in our region, and has forged a vision of the future which has opened the doors consistently to equality and opportunity and to a better Australia.

The decision of the Trades and Labour Council on that night 100 years ago this evening has led ultimately to an unprecedented decade of national Labor government. In my view, that is something all Australians can acknowledge and we in the labour movement in particular ought to celebrate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in Question Time Senator Tate was kind enough to answer a question of which I gave him previous notice. I seek leave to incorporate that question in Hansard. I have shown it to the Minister on duty in the chamber and he has agreed.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Given that a whole smorgasbord of subsidised imported food products is flooding into Australia at a cost of $2.134 billion or 10 per cent of the current account deficit; and given that these imports are causing great harm to our farmers and our horticultural industry; and given that most Australian shoppers would prefer to buy Australian products but find it difficult to distinguish between Australian and imported products on the supermarket shelves because of the present labelling regulations; will the Minister agree to enforce a code of labelling that will allow a shopper to readily identify Australian products by having the country of origin clearly marked on the label on the same side of the container as the contents and the brand name in lettering that is no less that 5mm? Will the Minister also investigate the loophole in the law which allows imported ingredients to be processed in Australia and then be labelled as a product of Australia, for example, imported fruit juice concentrate which is mixed with Australian water and labelled `Product of Australia'? Will the Minister give an assurance that he will give Australia a labelling code that ensures that there is accuracy and authenticity in labelling of imported foods?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the 1989-90 annual report of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee was tabled in the chamber. I would like to address a few remarks to that report. It is very important that we take notice of this report which is, in fact, a report of the first full year of operation of this Committee as it is now. The work of the Committee is particularly important to Australia's future. A significant part of the Committee's work is concerned with the community land care support subprogram. I am pleased to see in the report that funds available for land care projects have been increased through transfers from uncommitted areas of the national soil conservation program.

SPEECH.PARA: There has also been a steady shift of emphasis from simply the awareness programs to an increasing flexibility in the guidelines which are used to administer that. Page 7 of the report states this shift has:
made allowances for organisations and individuals not eligible for a grant under the Community Landcare Support sub-program to participate in soil conservation and landcare activities.

Because of that shift, we are now fortunately able to recognise the role played in the conservation of our soils by individuals. One such individual who has come to notice, certainly in Tasmania, is Mr David Stephen of Taroona. For his work during the past two decades at least Mr Stephen has been presented with an inaugural land care award for an individual non-primary producer.

While Mr Stephen is not mentioned in this report as a recipient of a land care grant, it is appropriate at this moment that the Senate also notes the efforts of individuals such as Mr Stephen in contributing to the welfare of Australia's basis for its primary production. Mr Stephen, for example, is particularly enthusiastic about sharing his knowledge with any other interested people. In the Hobart Mercury of 21 November it is reported that he holds classes to encourage people to care for the soil by replenishing its nutrients and protecting it from further deterioration. Mr Stephen is described as an ecological gardener who appreciates the need to maintain a natural balance when cultivating the soil.

When commenting on the Wool Research and Development Council's report some time ago I drew attention to that group's work with worms to improve pasture productivity. I mentioned the work of another individual in Tasmania, one of Tasmania's great agriculturalists, Mr Bert Farquhar of Rushy Lagoon. Like Mr Stephen, Mr Farquhar has persisted with farming practices which actually involve the assistance of what Mr Farquhar calls the invisible army-that is, the army of worms underneath the soil. The contribution made by the worms in this instance has greatly increased the productivity of the pasture. It is really important to note the contributions made by individuals such as these.

It is also important to note the efforts of other organisations. I turn to page 15 of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee's report. The point that Senator Calvert raised earlier struck me also. We have both recently travelled to the Northern Territory. I know that Senator Collins will be particularly thrilled about this. Although the Landcare program in the Northern Territory is described on page 15 of this report as being in its infancy, it has been identified that the main degradation issues being tackled are: the extensive degradation of native pastures; water erosion, particularly along perennial water courses; property planning; scalded land reclamation; rabbit control; and woody shrub invasion.

As I mentioned, I have just returned from public hearings in the Northern Territory conducted by the Select Committee on Animal Welfare. I am sure that the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee is aware of the information that was given to the Committee regarding the devastation being caused to Australia's soils, especially in the Northern Territory, by feral animals.

Without needing to go into the exact description of just how many feral animals there are and their categories, I think that the Senate, perhaps in anticipation, should make sure that its attention is drawn to the report which will come from the Animal Welfare Committee. The reference that was given to that Committee was to report on the animal welfare implications of the culling of large feral animals in the Northern Territory, but it was apparent during that Committee's visit that feral animals have the potential to destroy what is particularly Australian about our outback and, if left unchecked, will destroy our vegetation, our water systems-and thereby our soils-and also our native animal species.

Solving this massive problem is obviously beyond the capacity of the Landcare program that was described on page 15 of this report. But it is important to note that the program has begun and also that other programs exist which should assist in the overall conservation of Australia's soils.

This set-up that is described in this report is actually the best thing that has ever happened in this area of potential government expenditure. The Committee that has prepared the report in fact has the capacity to advise on and coordinate the funding of programs throughout Australia, and it is so doing. We can see from the report that State agencies received some $20.73m and that other organisations received $2.804m.

There are hundreds of organisations funded for a variety of programs as described in the report. I will just read a couple of them because I think it is important to be aware of the variety. For example, the Adelaide Hills Potato Growers Soil Conservation Committee was funded for $16,700 to conduct a program to reduce the risk of erosion from potato paddocks. In Tasmania the Bracknell-Liffey River catchment management project was funded for $6,000 and, as part of the research subprogram, the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and Fisheries was funded for $39,547 for a grass weed management for sustainable farming systems program.

The variety continues when we see that the Western Australia Department of Agriculture was funded for $7,000 to study the effects of tillage and run-off on soil loss. In Tasmania again, the Department of Primary Industries was funded for $16,591 for its midlands tree project. There are hundreds of programs throughout Australia, and this amazing variety of effort is in fact often conducted with the assistance of volunteers. I think that is an important point. The volunteers and community groups gain no particular individual financial benefit from successful programs, but are people who recognise the fundamental truth-that Australia's future and prosperity depend on the welfare of the soil.

There is no doubt that, as this program continues, so the number of applications for funding under it will rise from the 580-odd applications which were made this year as more people are aware of the usefulness of doing this sort of thing. The aims and the five major goals of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee are reported on pages 3 and 4 and will take only a second to read. I think it is important to do so. Those major goals are:
* that all lands in Australia be used within their capability;
* that soil conservation activity and land use decisions be based on whole catchment/regional land management planning concepts;
* that all land users and levels of government meet their respective responsibilities in achieving soil conservation.
* that effective co-operation and co-ordination occur between all sectors of the community, disciplines and agencies involved in the use and management of land and water resources; and
* that the community adopt a land conservation ethic.

I again emphasise that they are most worthy goals. But in reading this report, and in reading of the level of community support that there has been for it and the community interest there is in the programs, it occurred to me that the achievement of those five major goals would require a funding level realistically 10 times the amount that has been devoted to it here. While I subscribe to the objectives and endorse the activities so far, I would be much happier if there had been an indication during the Budget that a huge increase in funding had been proposed for this particular program.

It is amazing to see the effort that is already going into dealing with the problem, for example, in the Northern Territory. When faced with the magnitude of the problem of feral animals, and realising that this particular program devotes only something like $500,000 to the Northern Territory when, in fact, $50m might be required to address the feral animal problem properly, I think we can see that a huge funding increase would be necessary. I am not being at all critical of this program as it is; I would just like to see a lot more of it. With that, we would also be able to coordinate more effectively the many programs which have the capacity to address the problems of soil conservation in Australia.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Grants to Australian Council of Trade Unions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 15 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What grants has the Minister's department issued to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) during 1990-91.
(2) What grants, if any, does the Minister's department anticipate issuing to the ACTU during the remainder of 1990-91.
(3) What grants were paid by the Minister's department to the ACTU from the period April 1983 to June 1990, inclusive.

(4) For (1), (2) and (3) above, what were the details of the amount of each grant made, or anticipated to be made; the purpose for each of the grants made, or expected to be made; and the date that each of the grants was made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My department has made no grants to the ACTU in 1990/91.
(2) My department does not anticipate issuing any grants to the ACTU during the remainder of 1990/91.

(3) One grant each financial year from 1982/83 to 1989/90 was paid to the ACTU under the Migrant Worker's Rights Scheme. In April 1989 this scheme was renamed the Migrant Workers' Participation Scheme (MWPS). The responsibility for the MWPS was formally transferred from my portfolio to the Industrial Relations portfolio with effect from 17 September 1990.
(4) For (1) and (2), not applicable.
For (3) above:

The grants to the ACTU were in the form of a subsidy towards the cost of employing a worker to carry out an agreed program of work aimed at ensuring effective participation in the work place by migrants of non-English speaking background.

The subsidy grants were made up of a salary component and an ancillary component which provided for administrative and support costs. The Scheme is ``out-turn'' funded and thus the level of subsidy to the ACTU was adjusted yearly.
The grants to the ACTU were paid quarterly in advance.
